loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace has a lot of faith and courage and they have helped her overcome the poverty that afflicts her family. She is 41 years old and married. Grace has six children, all of whom look to her for support. She lives in the town of Cardona in the province of Rizal, Philippines.

In 1997, she joined ASHI, a Kiva field partner in the Philippines, to secure access to capital for her business, which consists of raising hogs. This loan is her ninth, and she has repaid the previous loans on time and made good use of them to expand her business and her income.
 
She has applied for a new loan of PHP 25,000 to buy additional piglets, sacks of feed and vitamins, and to pay for transportation expenses. 

She dreams of expanding her business into a full-fledged pig farm. She also dreams of sending her all children to school until they finish college and find great jobs. Until that happens, she is pleased at the way in which ASHI and Kiva have changed her family's life, out of poverty.

She says “salamat” (thank you) to ASHI and Kiva for sponsoring her for financial support and for giving them the opportunity to make their dreams come true.

loans.use: To buy additional piglets, sacks of feed and vitamins, and to pay for transportation expenses.

loans.name: Nyamdorj

texts.en:
Nyamdorj T. is 60 years old. He lives with his wife and three children in a small house and fence in Uvurhangai province in central Mongolia. Nyamdorj operates a small grocery store in his town. He sells a variety food products in his shop. After moving to his town in 2007, he started his grocery business by selling a variety of consumer goods from a stall at the local trade center. He has found success with his business in a short period and his earnings have enabled him to open his own grocery shop where he operates his business. In addition, he plants vegetables which he sells at the local market to supplement his earnings. In the future, he plans to expand his business by increasing his product line. He is a hardworking and modest and says, "My one goal is to increase my earnings so that I can provide a good education for my children." 

He is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan to purchase groceries so he can increase his working capital.

loans.use: To purchase groceries

loans.name: María Isidora

texts.es:
María Isidora tiene 29 años de edad, es casada y reside junto a su esposo y a sus hijos en el distrito de San José, una zona pesquera que pertenece a la provincia de Lambayeque y que se encuentra ubicada a  veinte minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo. 

Se dedica desde más de cinco años a trabajar en la venta de pescado procesado como seco – salado. Ella adquiere pescado fresco en el terminal pesquero de la región y lo procesa en algunos ambientes que se encuentran instalados cerca al mar. Usualmente ofrece en venta su mercadería en los diversos mercados de la región. Su esposo es pescador y suele ayudarla en el negocio durante la temporada de veda. Con estas dos actividades ellos tratan de sacar adelante a su familia y progresar.

María desea ampliar su negocio adquiriendo más pescado, de modo que pueda aumentar sus ventas y percibir mayores ganancias, por ello ha creído conveniente solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 2000 nuevos soles.

Ella ya ha tenido un préstamo financiado por el fondo Kiva, a través de Edpyme Alternativa y de su producto Capital Semilla, en aquella oportunidad también pudo adquirir más pescado fresco para procesarlo y gracias a esa inversión su negocio creció y con sus ganancias pudo realizar algunas mejoras en su vivienda. Ella se encuentra contenta y bastante agradecida con los prestamistas de Kiva.
texts.en:
Maria Isadora is 29 years old. She is married and lives with her husband and their children in the San José district, a fishing zone that belongs to the province of Lambayeque and is located 20 minutes from the city of Chiclayo.

She has been working for more than five years in the sale of processed fish, such as dried and salted fish. She acquires fresh fish at the regional fishing terminal and processes it in some facilities installed near the sea. Usually she offers her merchandise for sale in the various markets of the region. Her husband is a fisherman, and he usually helps in the business during the closed season. With these two activities, they are trying to raise their family and make progress.

Maria wants to enlarge her business by acquiring more fish, so that she can increase her sales and have better earnings. For this reason, she believed it would be convenient to apply to Edpyme Alternativa for a loan of 2000 PEN.

She has already had a loan financed by Kiva through Edpyme Alternativa and its product Capital Semilla (Seed Capital). With that opportunity she was also able to acquire more fresh fish to process, and thanks to this investment her business grew, and with her earnings she was able to complete some improvements in their home. She is happy with and quite grateful to the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Enlarge her business by acquiring more fish, so that she can increase her sales and receive greater earnings.

loans.name: Kung

texts.en: Mrs. Kung O. lives in Tuol Trea village, Takeo province and she is 55 years old. She just delivered a baby, so she does housework. She cooks delicious food for her family and she looks after the children, while her husband, Mr. Sam Nang Siem, is a farmer, construction worker and fisherman. With the plantation, she has some problems because her husband’s field has infertile soil. So, to improve production, Mrs. Kung O. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer and gasoline. She is going to hire farm laborers and oxen to plow the field. She is the mother of four children, who are all too young to work or study. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and gasoline

loans.name: Danny Daniel

texts.es:
Danny tiene 33 años de edad, es casado y reside junto a su esposa y a sus dos hijos en el distrito de Illimo, un distrito agrícola y comercial que pertenece a la provincia de Lambayeque y que se encuentra ubicado a más de una hora de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica desde hace varios años a la fabricación y venta de ladrillos, esta actividad fue enseñada por su padre y actualmente, debido al tiempo que tiene trabajando en el rubro, conoce a la perfección el manejo de su negocio. Danny cuenta con una clientela ya establecida y su negocio es bastante conocido en la zona. Los ingresos que percibe de esta actividad le sirven para sacar adelante a su familia.

Danny desea alquilar una parcela de terreno en donde tiene planeado instalar un horno que le permita aumentar su producción y percibir mayores ingresos, por ello ha creído conveniente solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 2000 nuevos soles que le ayuden a lograr su objetivo.
texts.en:
Danny is thirty-three years old, married and lives with his wife and their two children in the Illimo, an agricultural and commercial district that belongs to Lambayeque province. It is located more than an hour from the city of Chiclayo.

For many years now, his work has been the manufacture and sale of bricks, which he was taught by his father. Currently, due to the time he has spent working in this area, he knows how to run his business perfectly. Danny relies on an already established clientele and his business is well known in the area. The income he makes from this activity helps him and his family to get ahead. 

Danny wishes to rent a parcel of land, on which he plans to install an oven to help him increase his production and increase his income. Because of this, he thinks it's advisable to request a loan of 2000 nuevos soles from Edpyme Alternativa to help him achieve his objective.

loans.use: To rent a parcel of land where he plans to install an oven which will allow him to increase production of bricks and to make more income.

loans.name: María Jessica

texts.es:
María Jessica es una madre de familia que tiene 29 años de edad y que reside junto a su esposo y a sus tres hijos en el sector Fundo Los Ayala, uno de los anexos que conforma el caserío Punto Nueve, una zona agrícola que pertenece al distrito de Mochumí, provincia de Lambayeque, se encuentra ubicada a media hora de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica a trabajar la crianza y venta de animales menores. Ella cría pavos, patos, cerdos y gallinas en la parte posterior de su domicilio, los alimenta de granos y pastos naturales. Cuando estos ya han alcanzado un buen nivel de desarrollo los ofrece en venta en el mercado Moshoqueque de la ciudad de Chiclayo. El negocio le permite ayudar a su esposo, que es agricultor, con el sostenimiento de la economía de su familia.

María desea adquirir alimento para sus animales, su objetivo es verlos desarrollarse rápidamente para obtener mayores ingresos por sus ventas. Para lograrlo se ha propuesto solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un préstamo de 1000 nuevos soles.
texts.en:
Maria Jessica is 29 years old and the mother of a family. She lives with her husband and their three children in the Fundo Los Ayala sector, one of the annexes that forms the village of Punto Nueve, an agricultural zone that belongs to the district of Mochumi in the province of Lambayeque. It is located half an hour from the city of Chiclayo.

She raises and sells small animals. She raises turkeys, ducks, pigs, and hens in the area behind her residence. She feeds them natural grains and foods. When they have reached a good level of development, she offers them for sale in the Moshoqueque market in the city of Chiclayo. This business allows her to help her husband, who is a farmer, in sustaining the family economy.

Maria wants to buy food for her animals. Her goal is to see them develop rapidly so that she can obtain better income from her sales. To accomplish this, she decided to apply to Edpyme Alternativa for a loan of 1000 PEN.

loans.use: Buy feed for her animals.

loans.name: Teodolinda

texts.es:
Teodolinda es una madre de familia de 50 años de edad que vive junto a su esposo y la última de sus cinco hijos en el sector Las Dunas, una zona marginal del distrito de Lambayeque, una zona comercial que se encuentra ubicada a 20 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Ella cuenta desde hace más de dos años con una pequeña bodega instalada en su domicilio, allí ella ofrece a sus clientes diversos productos de consumo diario, entre productos de primera necesidad y abarrotes. Con los ingresos que percibe de esta actividad ella se encarga de ayudar a su esposo, quien trabaja eventualmente como albañil, con el sostenimiento de la economía de su familia.

Teodolinda desea ampliar su negocio adquiriendo más mercadería para poder satisfacer la demanda con la que cuenta, aumentar sus ventas y percibir mayores ingresos, por ello ha creído conveniente solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1500 nuevos soles que le ayuden a lograr su objetivo.

Teodolinda ya ha tenido un préstamo financiado por el Fondo Kiva a través de Edpyme Alternativa y su producto Capital Semilla. En aquella oportunidad también compró mas productos y pudo ampliar su bodega. Actualmente ella se encuentra bastante contenta y agradecida con los prestamistas de Kiva.
texts.en:
Teodolinda is a mother, is 50 years old, and lives with her husband and the youngest of her five children in Las Dunas, a area outside the district of Lambayeque. This is in a commercial area located 20 minutes from the city of Chiclayo. 

She has had a small store in her home, where she offers her clients diverse products including general goods and groceries. With the income from this activity, she helps her husband, who works as a bricklayer, with the family’s expenses.

Teodolinda wants to grow her business by acquiring more merchandise so that she can satisfy her clients’ demands. To increase her sales and earn more income, she has come to Edpyme Alternative for a loan for 1500 nuevos soles. 

Teodolina has already had a loan from Kiva through Edpyme Alternativa. At that time, she also bought more products and was able to grow her store. At present, she is very happy and thankful for Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To grow her business by acquiring more merchandise to satisfy her clients' demands

loans.name: Mrs. Naem Nut Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan in Praveakney village, Takeo province consists of 15 people who have selected Mrs. Naem N. T. be the village bank president. They will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes T. improve their famiL. living. Mrs. Naem N. is a farmer who owns a two-hectare plot of land T. grow rice and vegetables T. sell T. support her famiL.. She breeds some chickens, too. In the crop field, she has some problems because her field has infertile soil. So T. improve production, Mrs. Naem N. is seeking a loan T. buy fertilizer, rice seed, and some chickens. With the rest of the loan, she is going T. buy some piglets for breeding T. start a new business. She is a widow with two children are both construction workers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, rice seed, and chickens

loans.name: María Elena

texts.es:
María Elena es una madre de familia de 39 años de edad que reside junto a su familia en el sector Boca Chica – Santa Lucía del distrito de Olmos, una zona agrícola y bastante comercial que se encuentra ubicada en la provincia de Lambayeque, a más de dos horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Ella cuenta con una pequeña bodega instalada en su domicilio, allí ofrece a sus clientes diversos productos de consumo diario entre productos de primera necesidad y abarrotes. El negocio cuenta con bastante acogida debido a que la localidad en donde reside se encuentra ubicada a varios kilómetros de distancia del pueblo central y no cuentan con acceso rápido a productos de consumo diario. Con los ingresos que percibe de esta actividad ella se encarga de ayudar a su esposo con el sostenimiento de la economía de su familia.

María desea ampliar su negocio adquiriendo más mercadería para poder aumentar sus ventas y percibir mayores ingresos, por ello ha creído conveniente solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles que le ayuden a lograr su objetivo.
texts.en:
María Elena is a mother, is 39 years old, and lives with her family in Boca Chico, Santa Lucía in the district of Olmos. This is an agricultural and commercial area located in the province of Lambayeque, which is more than two hours from the city of Chiclayo.

She has had a small store in her home, where she offers her clients diverse products including general goods and groceries. The business gets a lot of recognition because the area where she lives is located many kilometers from the central area, and people do not have easy access to daily-use products. With the income that she receives from this activity, she help her husband with the family’s expenses. 

María wants to grow her business by acquiring more merchandise so that she can increase her sales and earn more income. To do this, she has requested a loan for 1000 new soles from Edpyme Alternativa.

loans.use: To grow her business by acquiring more merchandise to increase her sales and earn more income

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian happily shared that the loan she borrowed from ASHI helps her maintain the growth of her business. Moreover, the income she gets from the business is very helpful in sustaining her family. Additionally, she was able to send her six children to school. Her dream is for her six children to complete college and look for better employment in the future. Because of poverty, there’s nothing to leave her children except a better education. She believes that education is a wealth that others cannot steal. 

Vivian hopes that someday she will be able to expand her direct selling of Avon products and Boardwalk supplies. Therefore, she is now requesting another Kiva loan of 25,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) in order to purchase additional needed stock. She believes that having more items will help her retain her current customers as well as attract new clients in the neighborhood.

Vivian has been a proud member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, since 2008. She is a dedicated member with regular attendance to weekly center meetings and a solid record of repayment on previous loans. Her long-term goals are to have a winning business and to invest in her home. Additionally, she hopes to maintain her business as a sustainable livelihood to support her family. She says thank you to all Kiva supporters around the world for the chance to reach her goals in life and for giving her the financial funds to pursue her business endeavor. She prays that her lenders will be blessed.

loans.use: To buy additional  Avon products and Boardwalk supplies  to sell

loans.name: Khum

texts.en: Mrs. Khum K. is a villager in Saen Ban village, Takeo province. She was born in 1958. She and her husband, Mr. Soeng Phoeuk, are farmers who own a small piece of land to grow both rice and vegetables to sell to support their family. They breed four cows too. Since her cow breeding is going well, she wants to expand. Therefore, Mrs. Khum K. is applying for a loan to buy another cow and a piglet for breeding to start a new business. She is a mother of five children, two of whom are waiters. Two others help in their parents’ business and one attends public school. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy a cow and a piglet

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en: Marilyn C. owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising pigs for breeding. She is 37 years old, married and has three school-aged children. They are from the village of Brgy. Abinganan, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. Marilyn has been in her business for over nine years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2008, Marilyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Marilyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 22,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Marilyn is requesting a new loan of 22,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new equipment and tools needed to expand the business. This will be her fourth loan from ASKI. She plans to use additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new equipment and tools to expand the business

loans.name: Juan Orlando

texts.es:
Juan tiene 51 años de edad, es casado y vive junto a su esposa y tres de sus cuatro hijos en el distrito de Olmos, ubicado a una hora y 45 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Desde hace 29 años de dedica a la reparación de artefactos electrodomésticos (televisores, grabadoras, planchas, etc.) en un pequeño local ubicado en el centro de la ciudad. Su trabajo es muy solicitado y es la única fuente de ingresos del hogar.

La continua demanda de sus servicios hace que siempre tenga que adquirir repuestos y renovarlos ya que se le agotan con facilidad. Juan desea renovar su stock de repuestos y de ese modo brindar un buen servicio, por lo que ha solicitado a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 soles.

Juan ya ha tenido créditos financiados por el Fondo Kiva a través de Edpyme Alternativa y su producto Capital Semilla. En aquella oportunidad también solicitó en crédito para adquirir repuestos y mejorar la calidad de su servicio. Juan se encuentra bastante agradecido con los prestamistas que le ayudaron a sacar adelante su negocio.
texts.en:
Juan is 51 years old, married, and lives with his wife and three of his four children in the District of Olmos, which is located an hour and 45 minutes away from the city of Chiclayo.

He has been repairing household appliances (televisions, recorders, irons, and other devices) for 29 years from a small shop located in the center of the city. His work is highly sought after and provides his only source of household income.

The continued demand for his services always means that he must acquire spare parts to replenish his inventory that runs low easily. Juan wants to restock his inventory of parts so that he can provide good service, so he is requesting a loan from Edpyme Alternativa in the amount of 1000 PEN.

Juan has already received loans with Kiva funds through Edpyme Alternativa and its Seed Capital Product. By taking this opportunity to request a loan to acquire spare parts, he will be able to improve the quality of his service. Juan is very grateful to the lenders who are helping him succeed in his business.

loans.use: Purchase spare parts to restock his inventory

loans.name: Lucina

texts.es: Lucina G. R. de 51 años de edad, reside en el municipio de Panchimalco, en el departamento de San Salvador. Ella vive junto a su esposo y dos hijas mayores de edad, una de las cuales le ayuda con  el negocio. Lucina posee una tortillería desde hace 10 años, en el cual ha trabajado arduamente por el bienestar de sus hijas, así mismo posee una tienda y una pupusería, negocio de mucha importancia para ella ya que son estos los que le permiten contar con todo lo necesario para vivir.  Lucina solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda compra maíz para la elaboración de las tortillas y pupusas, así mismo queso chicharrón y frijoles,  esto debido a que cuenta con muy buena clientela, y ella desea poder atender a más clientes, puesto que en muchas ocasiones por falta de masa no ha podido atender a mas personas, es por ello que solicita el préstamo el cual le permita comprar más materia prima y así vender más y obtener mayores ganancias.
texts.en: Lucina G. R. is 51 years old, and lives in Panchimalco, in the department of San Salvador. She lives with her husband and two older children, one of whom helps with the business. Lucina has had a tortilla store for 10 years, and she has worked hard for the well-being of her daughters. She also has a store and a café. The businesses are very important to her because they allow her to have everything she needs to live. Lucina requests a loan so that she can buy corn to make tortillas and maize dumplings, as well as cheese, pork crackling, and beans. She has a good clientele and wants to be able to have more clients. Many times she cannot take on more clients because the she lacks dough. Because of this, she is requesting this loan so that she can buy more raw materials, sell more, and earn more income.

loans.use: To buy corn, beans, pork cracking, and other products

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en:
Jenny L. has been dedicating herself to expanding her business to support her dream of improving her family's quality of life.  She will be  very responsible with her loan obligations, and is thankful to the people who will support the loan she is requesting.  This loan will be very helpful in growing her business, so that her four children can fulfill their dreams of completing college and finding stable jobs.

Jenny runs her business to generate income to financially support her family. She would like to increase her weekly income. For this purpose, she applied for a new loan of 40,000 Php to purchase more stocks of firewood and to increase her working capital. Firewood, like charcoal, is the most common means of cooking food for poor people living in very remote areas of the province. Aside from its affordable price, firewood is also the most conveniently accessible commodity for everyone in distant villages. 

Most people in the villages cannot afford to buy a gas stove and gas to cook for their food.  Instead, they use firewood or charcoal as an alternative to a gas stove since it’s very expensive. 

Jenny has taken out many loans from ASHI and has repaid them successfully.  Therefore, she is trusted with much larger loans. Because of her 100% credit rating (on the basis of past loans) Jenny is also eligible for incentive loans for home repairs and education. These incentive loans are made only to very good members of ASHI, like Jenny. 

As active entrepreneur, Jenny would also like to explore additional businesses to provide her family a good living. Through business success, Jenny would like to invest in their own land to build a comfortable home to live in. 

Being a loyal member of ASHI for almost 5 years, Jenny wants to stay in ASHI for a long time because the institution is her second family.  It gave her and her family hope to start dreaming for a better life, out of poverty. 

She is very pleased to be a Kiva borrower, and says thank you to Kiva lenders for helping fund her business dreams. She prays that they will be blessed.

loans.use: To buy firewood to sell, and increase working capital

loans.name: Soun

texts.en: Soun S. is 30 years old.  She lives with her husband and two young children in Kompong Chhnang province. She works at home doing housework and cooking for her family. Her husband is the head of the family, earning US$7 every day to support the family. He has been a carpenter since 2009. He makes tables, chairs and beds, and sells them at the local market. Every month, this family spends about US$50 on food, US$10 on utility and US$30 on public transportation. Soun S. is asking for a loan of US$1000 to purchase a motorbike for her husband.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Melati Group

texts.en:
This group is chaired by Ni Ketut L.. There are 19 members who are applying for loans for the second time. However, not all members could attend the meeting because they were at Temple for the death of one of their neighbors. As is the habit of the villagers, if one of these people experience grief or a religious ceremony, it is the tradition that they have to perform activities of mutual cooperation to help each other.

This second loan was used to support their efforts in raising pigs. In addition to buying the pigs, the remainder of the loan was used to buy feed. This business is very supportive of the families in economic rural communities. Besides their farming, they could do this enterprise simultaneously. MUK,  through loans and training, directs members of the group to further enhance their skills in raising pigs so that they leverage their results. For now, there hasn't been a significant improvement that can be seen, but their knowledge of pig farming has been greatly improved with the provision of training by MUK. Pig farming is the main job they can do to improve their economy.

loans.use: To buy pigs and feed.

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en:
Juvy R. is from the town of Banga. She is 42 years old. Juvy is married and has four children. Her eldest child is 23 years old and the youngest is 10. To make a living, Juvy owns & operates a business planting and harvesting corn for sale. Juvy also plants fruits like guava.

Juvy joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juvy has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Juvy is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase organic fertilizers and other farm supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's school fees.

loans.use: To purchase organic fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida G. is from the town of Banga. She is 55 years old. Leonida is married and has three children aged 28, 25 and 22. To make a living, Leonida owns & operates a business planting & harvesting corn for sale. Leonida wishes to be a successful businesswoman.

Leonida joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonida has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Leonida is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers and seeds. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Bean

texts.en: Bean R., 45, is a widowed farmer who lives with one of her children in the Kampong Chhnang province. To earn a living, she grows rice and sells doormats at the local market. On average, she is able to make about US$4 profit each day. She is also supported by her son, Oum Nithy, who makes about US$2 each day as a garment factory worker. Bean R. would like to take out a loan of US$1,000 to purchase a motorbike for her son to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Marlon

texts.en:
Marlon F. is from the town of Banga. He is 41 years old. Marlon is single. To make a living, Marlon owns & operates a business planting and harvesting rice and corn for sale. Marlon works hard to build his business.

Marlon joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marlon has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Marlon is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
36-year-old Mary Ann B. is from the town of Banga. She is married and has two children aged 10 and 14. Mary Ann started her farming business four years ago. She plants and harvests corn crops that she sells at the market. Mary Ann works hard to sustain her family and her children's education.

Mary Ann joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Ann has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Mary Ann is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to buy seeds and fertilizers. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Cheoung

texts.en: Cheoung C., 56, sells groceries, earning an income of USD 10 per day. C. is married and resides with her husband and four children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkor Wat Temple. The family has to spend USD 70 on food, USD 5 on electricity supply, and USD 15 on other necessary expenses every month. Two of her children are employed, earning an income of about USD 10 each per day to help cover the family expenses.  C. is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase more groceries to stock the store. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Julius  Olondanga

texts.en: Julius has been in the mining business in Naivasha town for the last six years. He is 38 years old and married to Roselyn Abiyo. They have three  school-age children. He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend who is also a member of KADET. This will be his first loan which he plans to use to buy working tools e.g. mallet and mattock. In the future, Julius hopes his business will grow and get more work from the Kenyan government.

loans.use: to buy working tools e.g. mallet and mattock.

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane G., 28 years old, is from the town of Banga. She is married and has two children aged 18 and 15. To make a living, Mary Jane owns & operates a business planting & harvesting corn for sale. Mary Jane wishes to have a successful business and a stable income. She wants to be able to provide all her family's needs.

Mary Jane joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Jane has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Mary Jane is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase seeds and fertilizers. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Munh-Yurtunts

texts.en:
Munh-Yurtunts is 34 year old and lives with her daughter in Uvurhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her two sons live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent in her sister's fence. Her daughter attends a local secondary school. Munh-Yurtunts operates a clothing retail business out of a rented stall at the local trade center. She started her business in 2002 and has since gained a significant experience as a businesswoman. 

She received the loan from Xac Bank previously and had proven himself as a trustworthy customer. She needs more funds in order to expand her work place and increase her product line. In the future, she hopes to continue her success and grow her business. She says, "All I want is to educate my daughter and help her to become a successful business person in the future" She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes

loans.name: Hay

texts.en:
Hay S., 41, is a farmer, earning an income of USD 5 per day. S. is married and resides with her husband and nine children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkor Wat Temple. The family has to spend USD 60 on food, USD 10 on electricity supply, and USD 25 on other necessary expenses every month. 

S. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase cows to help plow her rice field. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy cows

loans.name: Consolata

texts.en: Consolata is forty eight years old, married with seven children living in her own house in Fort Portal Uganda. The responsibility to look after the family is vested in her and her dream is to build a permanent house for residence. For twenty years she has been  farming and the income generated has helped her pay school fees for her children and her business plan is to farm extensively. Consolata needs the loan to prepare the garden for cassava planting

loans.use: Preparing the garden for cassava planting

loans.name: Marng

texts.en:
Marng B., 45, grows corns and raises pigs, earning an income of USD 7 per day. B. is married and resides with her husband and three children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for the Angkor Wat Temple. The family has to spend USD 35 on food, USD 10 on electricity supply, and USD 7.5 on other necessary expenses every month.

 B. is requesting a loan of USD 450 to purchase a mechanical plow to help plow the rice fields. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. B. appears in the photograph with her husband.

loans.use: To buy a mechanical plow to help plow the rice field

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en:
Sorn C., 48, is a tailor, earning an income of USD 1 per day. C. is married and resides with her husband and four children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for the Angkor Wat Temple. The family has to spend USD 120 on food, USD 10 on electricity supply, and USD 30 on other necessary expenses every month. 

C. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase a motorbike for the family use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for the family use

loans.name: Tumendemberel

texts.en:
Tumendemberel D. is a 43 year old single mother who lives with her daughter in Uvurhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her daughter live together in an apartment which was bought with a bank loan and she is still paying off her loan. Her daughter attends a local high school and Tumendemberel operates a clothing  business out of a rented stall at the local trading center in her town. She sells a variety of clothes and earns a good profit which is used for her household's consumption. She started her clothes selling business in 2005 and has since built a stable and successful operation. She has found a success with her trade and has established a large loyal clientel over the years. She is working very hard to increase her earnings in order to pay off her apartment loan. Her dream is to provide a good education for her daughter. 

She is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase more clothing items at wholesale price for her clothes sales business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing items at wholesale price

loans.name: Phard

texts.en:
Phard S., 34, produces rice wine and grows rice, earning an income of USD 3 per day. S. is married and resides with her husband and two children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for  the Angkor Wat Temple. The family has to spend USD 20 on food, USD 10 on electricity supply, and USD 8 on other necessary expenses every month. 

S. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase pigs to raise. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To purchase pigs to raise

loans.name: Rem

texts.en:
Rem R., 48, sells groceries, earning an income of USD 5 per day. R. is married and resides with her husband and three children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for the Angkor Wat Temple. The family has to spend USD 15 on food, USD 5 on electricity supply, and USD 8 on other necessary expenses every month. 

Remt is requesting a loan of USD 900 to help her child get married. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: to help her child get married

loans.name: Francis

texts.en: Francis is a thirty six year old married man with four children living in his own house in Fort Portal Uganda. His dream is to provide a sustainable income for his family. He trades in produce for three years now and the business has been  lucrative with a slow but steadily expansion. Francis intends to use the loan to buy maize and beans for resell

loans.use: Purchasing maize and beans for resell

loans.name: Huatbek

texts.en:
Huatbek K. is 38 years old and lives with his wife and three sons in Bayan-Ulgii province in western Mongolia. He and his family live together in a house. All of his three sons attend a local secondary school. Huatbek operates a grocery shop next to his house. He started his grocery trading business in 2000 and has since built a stable and successful operation with his shop. His wife helps with his business by working as a salesperson in their grocery shop. Huatbek makes his procurement from a local wholesale market and sells a variety of grocery products by adding 15-20% on to the price. 

Today his working capital exceeds 1,500,000 MNT and his daily sales income has reached between 20,000 and 30,000 MNT while his monthly net profits are between 150,000 and 200,000 MNT. After years of operation, he was able to buy a motorcycle which enabled him to operate a taxi service to supplement his earnings. Huatbek obtained a loan from the bank previously and paid off his loan on time in full.

 He is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to buy a large amount of grocery products in order to sell at his shop.

loans.use: To buy a large amount of grocery products

loans.name: Josephine's Group

texts.en:
Josephine C. is from the village of Del C., Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 23 years old. Josephine is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Josephine is married and has 1 infant-aged child. To make a living, Josephine owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising chicken for sale. Josephine has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 4500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Josephine joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase breeding livestock. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Josephine from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase breeding livestock

loans.name: Myangantsetseg

texts.en:
Myangantsetseg B. is a 26 years old young lady who lives with her mother and sister in Arhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her sister is a university student. 

Myangantsetseg manages a clothing trade business out of a rented stall at the local trade center in her town. She sells a variety of jeans. She started her clothing business in 2007 and has built a stable operation. Today, her working capital exceeds 2,500,000 MNT. For the future, she hopes to continue to grow her business and have her own shop. Myangantsetseg is a hardworking and open minded person and says, "I want to sell latest design clothes for my customers." She is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase evening dresses in to sell during the upcoming holiday.

loans.use: To purchase evening dresses

loans.name: Tsendjav

texts.en: Tsendjav M. is 23 years old and lives with his wife and parents in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. They live in a wooden house. For three years, he has operated a clothing and cosmetics sales retail business with his wife. They run their business at the most crowded market in city. His parents are retired and he has no children yet. Tsendjav is planning to have their own plot of land with a house. He is a very optimistic person and he has been working hard to achieve his dream. He is requesting a 300,000 MNT loan to purchase some spare parts for his car.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for his car

loans.name: Noun

texts.en: Noun P., 58, is married and lives with her husband in the Kompong Chhnang province. She grows rice and makes US$4 of profit a day, while her husband works as a soldier. Noun P. is asking for a loan of US$1200 to purchase fertilizer, gas and rice seed.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, gas and rice seed.

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en: Patrick is a forty two year old married man with five children living in an owned house in Fort Portal Uganda hoping to secure a stable income in the future. He charges batteries for a living and has been in this business for three years which has enabled him to secure school fees for his children, he started as a laborer and later set up his own business. Patrick intends to use the credit to buy a battery charging machine.

loans.use: To buy a battery charging machine

loans.name: Tungalagtamir

texts.en:
Tungalagtamir D. is 31 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Arhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her two oldest children attend a local primary school while her husband operates a taxi service, started in 2004, using his own car. He has gained many permanent customers over the years. 

Tungalagtamir operates a consumer goods retail business out of a rented stall at the local market. She started her consumer goods sales business in 2009 after operating a flour sales business between 2002 and 2009. She has found success in her trade and has used her earnings to support her family. 

Today, her working capital exceeds 1,000,000 MNT. In the future she hopes to continue her success and grow her business. She is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to import a variety of clothing items from Erlian, a border city of China,  to resell at her stall.

loans.use: To import a variety of clothing items from Erlian

loans.name: Cyprian

texts.en: Cyprian M. is 37 years old, married, and has two children, both of whom attend school.  He runs a barber shop at Kagundo. Cyprian was introduced to KADET LTD by the credit officer in charge of the Tala office.  Cyprian has been running this business for 10 years and his monthly profit is 10,000 KES. This 30,000 KES loan is Cyprian's fourth loan from KADET LTD and his previous loans were paid on time. He intends to use the loan to buy new shaving machines, chemicals, and towels. If this loan boosts the business Cyprian will pay school fees and buy food for his children.  He dreams of having a big barber shop and he describes himself as hardworking.

loans.use: To buy new shaving machines, chemicals, and towels

loans.name: Soun

texts.en: Soun S., 38, is a professional tailor in Kampong Chhnang province. She is married with five children who are still living at home, and her husband works in security. She typically makes about $6 USD each day. Soun S. would like a loan to purchase a motorbike. In order to increase her profits, she is asking for $200 USD to purchase a motorbike for her husband to operate a moto-taxi.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Mi

texts.en: Mi R., 54, is a farmer, earning an income of $2.5 USD per day. R. is married and lives with her husband and three children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for the Angkor Wat Temple. The family has to spend $65 USD on food, $10 USD on electricity supply, and $7.5 USD on other necessary expenses every month. R. is requesting a loan of $400 USD to purchase a water pump. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her sixth loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. R. appears in the photograph with her husband.

loans.use: To buy a water pump

loans.name: Volodymyr

texts.en:
Volodymyr is married with two children. He is a small entrepreneur from Beregovo offering rental services. He owns non-residential property and leases it to clients. All his premises are located in the nice neighborhoods of Beregovo. Volodymyr has been in this business for five years. His net profit amounts to 6,000 UAH per month.
Volodymyr is seeking a loan of 6,000 UAH to remodel the facility he is going to rent after remodeling is finished. Volodymyr believes that interior improvements will attract potential clients and help him set higher rental rates. He is hoping to continue investing his income in property thus expanding his business and renting out to more and more clients.
Note: in the photo Volodymyr is standing in front of one of his rented facilities.

loans.use: To remodel a rental facility

loans.name: Rem

texts.en: Rem H., a farmer earning an income of USD 2 per day, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for the Angkor Wat Temple. The family has to spend USD 35 on food, USD 6 on electricity supply, and USD 10 on other necessary expenses every month. H. is now requesting a loan of USD 800 to help her child get married. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To help her child get married

loans.name: Edlie

texts.en:
Edlie L., from the village of Magsaysay, Naguillan, Isabela, is 46 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Edlie owns and operates a business venture in the food sector preparing and selling barbecue pork and chicken and juices for sale. Engaged in her business for over 10 years, she earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Edlie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale, she is now requesting her fourth loan of 18000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and use as working capital. Edlie plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Oum

texts.en: Oum S., 39, is a garment factory worker in Kampong Chhnang province. She is married with three children who are still living at home, and her husband works as a policeman. She and her husband typically make about $4 USD combined. Oum S. is asking for a loan of $500 USD to purchase a motorbike to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en:
Sylvia G. is from the town of Banga. She is 40 years old, married and has four children aged 15, 12, 9 and 3. To make a living, Sylvia owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector planting and harvesting corn for sale. Sylvia started her business five years ago and earns approximately 4,000 PHP per month.
Sylvia joined Kiva partner, CEVI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Sylvia is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to buy seeds and fertilizers. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Sek

texts.en: Sek R., 48, sells chickens and rice, earning an income of $8 USD per day. R. is married and lives with her husband and four children in Siem Reap province, Cambodia, an area known for the Angkor Wat temple. The family has to spend $50 USD on food, $15 USD on electricity supply and $50 USD on other necessary expenses every month. R. is requesting a loan of $1,000 USD to purchase a motorbike to transport chickens and rice for resale. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to transport chickens and rice for resale

loans.name: Horm

texts.en:
Horm Y., 37, a farmer who also purchases rice to resell, earns an income of U.S. $5 per day. Y. is married and resides with her husband and four children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkor Wat and other temples.

Y.'s family spends U.S. $50 on food, $10 on electricity, and $30 on other necessary expenses every month. Y. is requesting a loan of U.S. $500 to purchase a motorbike with an attached trailer in order to transport rice to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit she makes to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike with an attached  trailer in order to transport rice to sell

loans.name: Khun

texts.en:
Khun S., 23, is employed at a hotel, earning U.S. $1.50 per day. S. is married and resides with her husband in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkor Wat and other temples.

Her family spends U.S. $50 on food, $15 on electricity, and $30 on other expenses every month. S. is requesting a loan of U.S. $700 to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: to repair a house

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks for her pub

loans.name: Glenda

texts.en:
Glenda is mother devoted to her only child, Rhodges. She is married to her loving spouse, Roy M., a welder, and lives on beautiful Talim Island in Binangonan, Rizal Province. She and her husband have a fishing business and a hog fattening business. Despite many challenges they have faced in their life, they have never given up fighting against poverty.

Glenda plans to utilize this loan of 25,000 Philippine pesos to expand her hog fattening business. This loan will be used to pay for more fattening agents and feeds.   Hog fattening is a common business for people in the area and Glenda feels the financial opportunity of hog fattening is one best way to provide for the basic needs of her family.  Hogs take approximately four to six months until they are ready for sale, and after that period of time the pigs will be either be sold alive or slaughtered for their meat.

During her six years at Kiva partner microfinance institution ASHI, Glenda has shown very good performance as a member by maintaining an excellent repayment status and by having a good attendance record at meetings.  She hopes this loan will enable her to finally reach her dreams in life: to have a fully-fledged pig farm business, a good life and happy family, and a house that is free from flooding.

loans.use: to buy for more fattening agents and feed for pigs

loans.name: Kigando Abeteraine Group

texts.en:
Grace is a thirty-eight-year-old married woman with six children who lives in her own house in Fort Portal, Uganda. She is a member of the Kigando Abeteraine borrower group (pictured in the photo that accompanies this profile), in which each member of the group guarantees the loans of the other.

Grace is charged with the responsibility of looking after her family, and her dream is to be able to educate all her children up to the university level. She has been running a small retail shop for ten years which has boosted her income level.  Her business plan is to become a wholesale trader.  Grace needs her portion of this group loan to buy sugar, coffee, soap and salt to sell at her shop.

loans.use: to buy sugar, coffee, soap and salt for to resell in a shop

loans.name: Margaret Muthue

texts.en:
Margaret Muthue, age 30, runs a salon at Tala market. She is married to David Wambua, age 42, who is employed and together they have three children: Brenda age 10, Faith age six, and Solomon age three. Margaret was introduced to KADET by the credit officer in charge of the Tala office.

Margaret has been  running this salon for a period of one year. This loan of Kshs10,000 is Margaret's first loan from KADET. Margaret intends to use the loan to buy cosmetics, hair oil and weaves. If the loan boosts the business, Margaret will pay school fees for her children and buy food for them.

Margaret  dreams of owning a big salon. She describes herself as hardworking.

loans.use: To buy weaves, hair oil and cosmetics.

loans.name: Vourn

texts.en:
Vourn E., 26, grows rice and raises pigs, earning U.S. $5 per day. E. is married and resides with her husband and two children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkor Wat  and other temples.

Her family spends U.S. $50 on food, $10 on electricity, and $90 on other expenses every month. E. is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase pig food and pigs to raise for sale. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit from her business to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: to buy pig food and pigs to raise for sale

loans.name: Heng

texts.en: Heng N. is married with four young children living at home in the Kampong Chnang province. She works in a grocery store, typically making US $5 each day. Her husband catches and sells fish. Her husband typically makes about US $2 each day. Heng N. would like a loan of US $600 to purchase more grocery products to sell.

loans.use: To buy more grocery products to sell

loans.name: Florijoy

texts.en:
Florijoy Y. is from the village of Brgy. Homestead, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 26 years old. Florijoy is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Florijoy owns and operates a motorcycle transport service. Florijoy has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Florijoy joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Florijoy is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to repair her vehicle for better service. This will be the first loan taken by Florijoy from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to financially support her family. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Chheng

texts.en:
Chheng E. is a houswife. She is married and resides with her husband and a child in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for the Angkor Wat Temple. 

The family has to spend US $30 on food, $5 on electricity, and $15 on other necessary expenses every month. 

Her child is employed at a hotel, earning an income of US $4 per day to help cover the family expenses. E. is requesting a loan of US $1000 to purchase a motorbike for her child to commute to work. 

In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her child to commute to work

loans.name: Si

texts.en:
Si Y., 51, sells traditional cakes, earning an income of US $3 per day. Y. is married and resides with her husband and two children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for the Angkor Wat Temple. 

The family has to spend US $50 on food, $6 on electricity, and $55 on other necessary expenses every month. 

Y. is requesting a loan of US $500 to buy a motorbike for the children to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for the children to commute to work

loans.name: Im

texts.en:
Im P., 25, is a farmer, earning an income of US $3 per day. P. is married and resides with her husband and three children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for the Angkor Wat Temple. 

The family has to spend US $50 on food, $10 on electricity, and $40 on other necessary expenses every month. P. is requesting a loan of US $800 to purchase a motorbike for family use and to purchase pigs to raise. 

In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy  a motorbike for family use and to buy pigs to raise

loans.name: Dukundumurimo Group

texts.en:
Beatrice is 41 years old, married and has three children between the ages of four and twenty.  Two of her children go to school. Beatrice is a group leader of the borrowing group Dukundumurimo in Kinyarwanda which means "let's love our work" in English.

All group members are determined to receive this loan and are committed to repaying their loan as well. They say that their businesses are very crucial and attractive to their customers.

Beatrice sells local soft drinks, which she has been doing for four years. Her husband is a businessman.  Beatrice will use the loan to purchase and add more production of local soft drink.  With the new profits from her expanded business, Beatrice plans to pay school fees for her children for further studies.

loans.use: To buy soft drinks and produce more local drinks to sell.

loans.name: Yun

texts.en:
Yun K., 33, sells fish and vegetables, earning an income of $5 US per day. K. is married and resides with her husband and three children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for the Angkor Wat Temple.

The family has to spend $50 US on food, $7 US on electricity supply, and $80 US on other necessary expenses every month. K. is requesting a loan of $700 US to purchase more fish and vegetables to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy fish and vegetables to resell

loans.name: Mork

texts.en:
Mork S., 36, is a farmer earning an income of 2 USD per day. S. is married and resides with her husband and five children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of 3 USD per day. The family has to spend 50 USD on food, 5 USD on electricity supply, and 7 USD on other necessary expenses every month.

S. is requesting a loan of 700 USD to purchase a machine to cut firewood for sale. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a machine to cut firewood for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To renovate the daycare and buy initial supplies and toys

loans.name: Dinara's Group

texts.en: Dinara S. is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Karabalta, a small town near Bishkek (the capital of Kyrgyzstan). She is 49 and married. She has two daughters and a son. The first daughter works as a cook, the second is engaged in trade and the son studies at university A year ago, with the initial investment of 10,000 soms, Dinara and her husband started to breed cattle. Reselling cattle after fattening, they earn 3,700 soms per month. That profit made it possible for them to save money and purchase home furniture. Dinara applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase a calf in order to increase the number of cattle. In the future she wants to improve the family’s living conditions and purchase a vehicle. ====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to purchase a calf

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 23-year-old single man who lives with his parents. He is from Lebanon. Despite his young age, he has been making pastries for over eight years and he opened his own pastry shop in 2006. His freshly prepared goods are enjoyed by members of his village and neighboring towns. He helps his father to meet the family's expenses.  

Today, he is requesting a loan of $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additional merchandise that he needs, such as flour, sugar, and oil, so he is prepared for the coming holidays. He also wants to increase his productivity and further develop his shop. He is planning to continue expanding his business and he is positive about the coming year. 

His bakery is an important source of income for his family. Lebanon has many pastry shop and bakeries and it is easy to buy fresh goods in one’s village or neighborhood.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise

loans.name: Nem

texts.en:
Nem N., 45, is a farmer earning an income of 2 USD per day. N. is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations.  The family has to spend 80 USD on food, 3 USD on electricity supply, and 15 USD on other necessary expenses every month.

N. is requesting a loan of 600 USD to purchase a motorbike for the family to use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a motorbike for the family to use

loans.name: Kuy

texts.en:
Kuy K., 45, is a farmer. K. is married and lives with her husband and eight children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. Her husband is a skilled carpenter who earns an income of USD $3.00 per day. The family has to spend USD $58.00 on food, USD $3.00 on electricity, and USD $4.00 on other necessary expenses every month. 

K. is requesting a loan of USD $1000 to purchase a motorbike for family use. In the future, she would like to use her profits to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva field partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for family use

loans.name: Miriam

texts.en:
Miriam has just an elementary school education but through KIEDF has learned to manage her business and price her jewelry so that it draws business and ensures her family a worthwhile profit. She has become a wise businesswoman. Miriam began her business buying pieces of jewelry and fixing them for resale. At first she worked in gold but the cost proved too high. She switched to buying silver and ever since has gained a large clientele and an excellent reputation. Miriam's business model is to create the products and bring them to her customers in their homes, businesses or at special events. This has proven effective in building her client base and ensuring a steady income. Now she sells silver pieces she has purchased and fixed, as well as some pieces she designs and creates on her own. 

Miriam is taking out this loan to purchase additional raw materials and jewelry to increase her stock and meet additional demand. Miriam wants to take a jewelry design course so she can begin to create more of her own pieces. She wants to create a jewelry line of her own to answer the needs of women in her area. Miriam is an extremely strong woman. She supports her family completely with her income. Before KIEDF, she did not think she could open a business, but now, she cannot imagine not having hers.

loans.use: To stock jewelry pieces

loans.name: Uy

texts.en:
Uy C., age 47, sells traditional Cambodian cakes, from which she earns an income of USD $2.00 per day. C. is married and lives with her husband and seven children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. Her husband raises ducks and earns an income of USD $2.00 per day. The family has to spend USD $50.00 on food, USD $2.00 on electricity, and USD $4.00 on other necessary expenses every month. 

C. is requesting a loan of USD $600 to purchase fish to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy fish to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Nol Dieng Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Nol D. is a mother of four children, two of whom are employed in garment factories while another one is a weaver and the youngest is 15 years old. She is the  village bank president who has been selected by sixteen people who make up a village bank in Krang Chamraeun village, Takeo province. They are asking for a  loan in which each of their portion of the loan can improve their family living conditions. 

Mrs. Nol D. is a weaver who earns  money to support her family while her husband, Mr. Sum Hing, is a village chief and a farmer.He owns a half-hectare plot of land to grow rice to sell and  also supports the family. Now that her business is going well Mrs. Nol D. wants to expand. For this purpose, Mrs. Nol D. is seeking  a loan to buy more silk.

loans.use: To buy more silk

loans.name: Orna

texts.en:
Orna is a single mother of two who is working hard to ensure a better future for herself and her children. She has important emotional support from her parents, enabling her to open her business while studying for her Masters in Education. Orna is a private tutor and instructor from the prestigious Israeli Bar Ilan mathematics program for elementary through high school students. Orna is opening a math tutoring business for groups. She has a strong base of potential clientele from her existing tutoring and education connections. There is a strong need in Tel Aviv for math tutors, especially at Orna's level. The draw of group tutoring as opposed to individual is large since it holds down the individual costs for students, while creating a supportive small group atmosphere as well. For Orna, it means a larger amount of per hour income as opposed to one-on-one tutoring. 

The loan is needed to pay for renovations to create a classroom setting, supplies and advertising.

Orna will use her current connections with different schools in the area. With this loan, she is moving her business to a location with increased diversity and higher socio-economic possibilities. In the future, Orna wants to expand her business and hire additional tutors to work with the ever-growing number of student groups.

loans.use: To pay for renovations to create a classroom setting, supplies and advertising.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for renovations on an extra classroom and for supplies for afterschool activities

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for renovations and purchase toys and supplies

loans.name: Raikan's Group

texts.en:
Raikan A. is the leader of this group. She is the resident ok Kerben, a small town in the south of Kyrgyzstan.  Raikan, age 23, is married to a taxi driver.  She has a newborn daughter. Two years ago with an initial investment of 20000 soms, the family started to breed livestock. By reselling livestock after fattening, they earn 9000 soms per month. This profit made it possible for them to save money and purchase a vehicle. 

With the money from this loan, Raikan wants to purchase animals so she can expand her business. In the future, she plans to make house repairs. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Chou

texts.en:
Chou S., age 42, is a farmer who earns an income of USD $2.00 per day. S. is married and lives with her husband and five children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. Her husband grows cucumbers and earns an income of USD $5.00 per day. The family has to spend USD $39.00 on food, USD $3.00 on electricity, and USD $9.00 on other necessary expenses every month. 

S. is requesting a loan of USD $1200 to purchase fish to raise. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits to repair her house. This is her fourth loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy fish to raise

loans.name: Khut

texts.en:
Khut T., age 49, sells ice cream and earns an income of USD $2.50 per day. T. is married and lives with her husband and four children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. The family has to spend USD $83.00 on food, USD $5.00 on electricity, and USD $32 on other necessary expenses every month. 

T. is requesting a loan of USD $600 to purchase a motorbike for one of the children to use when selling ice-cream. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to use when selling ice cream

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 30-year-old married man and the father of one child who attends school. He is from Lebanon. He has been working in iron production for over six years. He started his own business in 2006.  His work is very delicate and he works hard to satisfy the needs of his family. Over the years, he has been able to build a good business reputation. 

Today, he is requesting a loan of $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase special iron machinery that will facilitate his productivity. This machinery will help him deliver his goods faster and expand his business operations. He is planning to continue expanding his business and he is positive about the coming year.

loans.use: To purchase special iron machinery

loans.name: Mrs. Oeurng Pov Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of thirteen people who live in Krang Chamraeun village, Takeo province. All the members have selected Mrs. Oeurng P. to become the village bank president. They will use their portion of the loan for different purposes which  can improve their family's living conditions. 

Mrs. Oeurng P., a widow with a child who is five years old, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to grow rice to sell to support her family and she also weaves silk. Since her weaving is going well, she wants to expand. Mrs. Oeurng P. is asking for a loan to buy more silk.

loans.use: To buy more silk to weave.

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mao S., age 40, is a housewife. S. is married and lives with her husband and four children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. Her husband is hired to plow rice fields and earns an income of USD $3.00 per day. The family has to spend USD $45.00 on food, USD $5.00 on electricity, and USD $20.00 on other necessary expenses every month. 

S. is requesting a loan of USD $1000 to purchase a plot of farmland to earn more income. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy farmland

loans.name: Nub

texts.en:
Nub C., age 44, is a housewife. She is married and lives with her husband and two children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. Her husband manufactures and sells cement pipes and steps, earning an income of USD $6.00 per day. The family has to spend USD $40.00 on food, USD $5.00 on electricity, and USD $38.00 on other necessary expenses every month. 

C. is requesting a loan of USD $1200 to purchase more supplies to improve her husband’s business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy supplies to improve her husband's business

loans.name: Angelino's Group

texts.en:
Angelino S. is from the village of Linglingay in Cauayan City, Isabela. He is 50 years old. Angelino is the leader of a 5-member loan group sponsored by ASKI. Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Angelino is married and has 8 adult children. To make a living, Angelino buys and sells fruits and vegetables in the local community. Angelino has been engaged in his business for over 25 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Angelino joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Angelino has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Angelino is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Angelino from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & use as working capital

loans.name: Sem

texts.en:
