Sem S., age 49, is a housewife. S. is married and lives with her husband and four children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. Her husband is a farmer, earning an income of USD $3.00 per day. The family has to spend USD $40.00 on food, USD $5.00 on electricity, and USD $43.00 on other necessary expenses every month. 

S. is requesting a loan of USD $1000 to purchase a motorbike for family use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for family use

loans.name: Mrs. Hing Chreb Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mrs. Hing C. has been selected as the the village bank president in Krang Chamraeun village, Takeo province.  There are 10 members of this bank and they will use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their family's living conditions. Mrs. Hing C., a mother of two children who are students, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to grow rice to sell to support her family and she also weaves silk at her home. Her husband, Mr. Thol Ek, is a construction worker. Since her business is going well, Mrs. Hing C. wants to expand. She  is requesting  a loan to buy more silk for this purpose.

loans.use: To buy more silk

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 38-year-old married man and the father of one young child. He is from Lebanon. He has twenty years of experience painting cars. He is the main income provider for his family. He borrowed his first Kiva loan and he was a very reliable client who paid on time during the loan term. He is thankful for the results and today, he is requesting a new loan of $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l.  to increase his inventory of new paints and, therefore, increase his sales. He is optimistic about his business prospects for the coming years.

loans.use: To increase his inventory

loans.name: Kuteesa Women's Group-Lugazi

texts.en: 37-year-old K. Efulansi is a lady with willpower, conviction and diligence. A belief in her own worth has also been instrumental in her quest to firmly lay solid ground for the consolidation of her 20-year-old farming business in Luleeka-Lugazi. She has, in the course of the past 20 years, been selling mostly cash crops such as maize, rice, cassava, coffee, bananas, beans and also poultry. Prior to this, she was a teacher. She is casting her mind to the future now and she says she is planning to construct rental structures. Efulansi, who is happily married and has 4 kids, says her business generates  50,000 shillings weekly. Efulansi belongs to Kuteesa Women's group-Lugazi. With this loan, she says she is going to buy high grade manure for her farming gardens.

loans.use: The purchase of high grade manure for her gardens.

loans.name: Garegin

texts.en:
Garegin Z. is 56 years old. He lives in the Ddmashen Village, Sevan area with his wife and two school-aged children. His wife doesn't work, but cares for their children. 

Garegin has a higher education. He is a physicist and, for about 19 years, he worked in his specialty. But after 1996, because of changes in Armenia's economic situation, he lost his job. So he organized his own petrol and diesel oil business, which he runs from his garage. At the same time, Garegin is engaging in animal farming. Thanks to his two occupations, Garegin supports his family and saves money for his children's higher education.
    
Garegin is asking for a loan of 1,000,000 Armenian drams to buy petrol and diesel oil for his business.

loans.use: To buy petrol and diesel oil for his business

loans.name: Guljan's Group

texts.en:
Guljan B. is the leader of this group. She is the resident of Tashkomur, a small mining town in the south of Kyrgyzstan. She is 46 years old and is married to a truck driver. Together they are raising two daughters and a son. Nine years ago, with an initial investment of 10000 soms, Guljan opened a cafeteria. She earns 20000 soms per month. That profit made it possible for her family to start building a new house in Bishkek. With money received from the loanm Guljan wants to improve their living conditions and purchase a TV. In the future, she plans to finish the house construction.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase a television for her home

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 29-year-old single woman who lives with her parents. She is from Lebanon. She has run a successful coffee and nut-roasting shop for seven years. Her father is the main income provider for her family but as is common with the majority of the Lebanese families, they cooperate to pay for the high cost of living.

She obtained a first Kiva loan and she is thankful for her decision. Today, she is requesting a new loan of $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to increase her store’s inventory of nuts, coffee and a variety of food products. With the new merchandise, she will increase her sales and her income. In the coming year, she plans to continue expanding her business.

loans.use: To increase her store’s inventory

loans.name: Mie

texts.en:
Mie P., age 33, sells pigs, earning an income of USD $6.00 per day. P. is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. Her husband sells rice, earning an income of USD $5.00 per day. The family has to spend USD $55.00 on food, USD $2.00 on electricity, and USD $40.00 on other necessary expenses every month. 

P. is requesting a loan of USD $800 to purchase more rice to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy rice to resell

loans.name: Lay

texts.en:
Lay V., age 49, sells groceries and is a tailor, earning an income of USD $6.00 per day. V. is married and live with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. Her husband works at a Christian church, earning an income of USD $3.00 per day. The family has to spend USD $66.00 on food, USD $3.00 on electricity, and USD $50.00 on other necessary expenses every month. 

V. is requesting a loan of USD $1200 to purchase more groceries to stock her store. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more groceries for her store

loans.name: Medilyn

texts.en:
Medilyn C. is a married woman who lives in Purok Bangkal, Barangay Bulanon, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by selling fish. Her husband Danilo C., who is 43 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business. They have 8 children who range in age from 1 month to 16 years old. Six of her children go to school. 

Medilyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 11 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Medilyn has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, thus improving the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 12th loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,500 which she intends to use as additional working capital so that she can continue to save for the future, sustain their daily needs, and educate their children. Medilyn C. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.  

The photo was not taken at her business because the fish was already delivered to her buyers.  

About NWTF:  
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.  Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie  L. is a 44-year old married woman who supports her family by operating  businesses, a general store and a school canteen. She lives in  Barangay San Juan in San Carlos City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and canteen, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 5,500. 

Elsie  is now borrowing PHP 14,000 so that she can buy more groceries to sell. This will be her 13th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 11,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Elsie  aspires to improve her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.  

About NWTF:  
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites M. is a 42-year old married woman who supports her family by operating 3 business ventures: a sari-sari (general) store, a pig-raising business, and a fish businesses. She lives in Purok Paglaum, Barangay Taba-ao, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her sari-sari (general) store, pig fattening and fish vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 5,000. 

Marites is now borrowing PHP 16,000 to use in her businesses. This will be her 10th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP14,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom.  Marites aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the Dungganon way.

"

loans.use: Funds for her businesses

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Khun

texts.en:
Khun K., a 42-year-old farmer earning an income of USD 1.5 per day, is married and resides with her husband, a factory worker earning USD 3 per day, in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its palm products. The family has to spend USD 50 on food, USD 2 on electricity supply, and USD 50 on other necessary expenses every month.

Khun is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase two cows to improve her farming business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy two cows to improve the farming business

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 54-year-old widow from Lebanon. She established a home business twenty-five years ago; she works as a hairdresser and beautician. She has prepared a speciA. room to receive the clients. She also works as an itinerant. To reinforce her business income, she also sells cosmetic products. 

Due to her long period of activity in this occupation, she has a good number of clients asking for her beauty services. Today, she is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to increase her stock of make-up and cosmetics products. In the future, she hopes to continue her work properly and earn a good income to provide better living conditions for herself because she lives alone and she is the main income provider with no support from others.

loans.use: to increase her stock of make-up and cosmetics products

loans.name: Khen

texts.en:
Khen E., 39, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-ankorean temples. Khen raises pigs at home, earning an income of USD 2 per day. The family has to spend USD 15 on food, USD 5 on electricity supply, and USD 28 on other necessary expenses every month.

Khen is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase duck eggs to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy duck eggs to resell

loans.name: Ahmed

texts.en:
Ahmed is from Tarqoumia Village in Hebron district. He is married and a father of one daughter and five sons. Ahmed built a house and now he is putting on the final touches, such as painting and installing tiles.

Ahmed is an employee with a decent salary so he only needed a loan from FATEN to cover the rest of the expenses to get the house ready for him and the family to move in by the end of this year.

Ahmed's picture was taken in FATEN's office while receiving the loan.

loans.use: To paint his house and install tiles

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a water pump

loans.name: Nhem

texts.en:
Nhem R., 45, is married and resides with her husband and six children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-ankorean temples. Nhem sells porridge, earning an income of USD 1.5 per day. The family has to spend USD 20 on food, USD 5 on electricity supply, and USD 20 on other necessary expenses every month.

Nhem is requesting a loan of USD 400 to purchase dishes and tents to rent for the events in the village, and plans to use any additional profit to repair her house. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy dishes and tents to rent for events in the village

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is an 18-year-old single man from Lebanon. He lives with his parents and five siblings. This young man has started working in car mechanics in 2002. And after getting the needed experience, he decided to open his own car repair shop. He repairs all type of cars. This talented man was able to gain a good number of clients. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase mechanic's tools. He wants to complete all tools needed to reinforce his business and be in demand with his clients. In the future, he hopes to expand his business further and sell car spare parts.

loans.use: to purchase mechanic's tools

loans.name: Lors

texts.en: Lors V., 47, is married with three children living at home in Kampong Chhnang Province. Lors sells sugarcane juice, typically making US$2.50 each day, while her husband, Mat Ly, operates a moto-taxi and typically earns about US$2 each day. Lors V. would like a loan of US$800 to purchase a trailer to attach to her husband’s motorbike.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer.

loans.name: Chor

texts.en: Chor C., 31, is a garment factory worker in Kampong Chhnang province. She is married with one child who is still living at home, and her husband is a farmer. She typically makes about US$ 3 each day, and would like a loan of US$ 400 to purchase a cow to help with farm work.

loans.use: To purchase a cow

loans.name: Nezzikokolima Development Group-Mukono

texts.en: 46-year-old Grace S. has been running a poultry business for the past 6 years in Kirinya-Mukono. It is a lucrative business. This happily married mother of 4 says she began her business out of self interest. Like any other business of this nature, she has been plagued by some long drawn out problems, such as constant chicken diseases that have, in most cases, killed many of her birds. She has chosen not to despair, but has worked painstakingly hard in trying to forestall the above mentioned problems through buying medicines and improving the hygiene of her chicken house. In a way, this has helped her a lot as her chickens are now growing up healthy, sturdy and free of disease and stress. As a result, she has been able to resell more chickens to more clients. Grace belongs to Nezzikokolima development group-Mukono. She says this business generates her 120,000 shillings weekly. With this loan, she says she is going to buy more chicks.

loans.use: Towards the purchase of more chicks.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 26-year-old married woman from Lebanon. She is the mother of one young child. She has almost five years of experience working as a make-up artist. Her business income is vitA. to help her husband with the family income especially to cover the child's expenses. She works from her home where she receives the clients. 

Today, she is requesting to borrow $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase make-up tools and products. She has high hopes for the future of her business; she is looking to continue the expansion of her business in the coming year. In the future, she hopes to open a formA. beauty salon where she can receive the clients. 

Women continue to play an important role in Lebanese society, especially in the development of the family. Women are able to serve as strong role models for their children while also helping to supplement their household incomes. In almost all parts of Lebanon, demand for beauty and fashion products continues to be high.

loans.use: to purchase make-up tools and products

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Keo S. is 31 years old and sells vegetables in Kampong Chhnang province. Her business has been around for about ten years and she makes US$ 7 every day. Her husband works collecting palm juice to refine to palm sugar. On average, he makes US$ 3 of profit each day. Selling vegetables has been a difficult business, as there is high inflation and weather conditions have not been conducive to a good growing season. She is asking for a loan of US$ 400 to invest in her vegetable business.

loans.use: To invest in her vegetable business.

loans.name: Nidal

texts.en:
Nidal Natshe is a young man from Hebron city. He is married and a father of four sons who are all in school. Nidal came to FATEN for a loan to fix his house's infrastructure, including the water and electricity networks. 

Winter is near and his house needs maintenance so he decided to perform it this month before rainy and windy weather attacks the region. Hebron is a cold city where it rains and snows heavily.

Nidal Natshe appears in the picture above in FATEN's office.

loans.use: To perform house and infrastructure maintenance on his home

loans.name: Sors

texts.en: Sors N., 34, is a garment factory worker in the Kampong Chhnang province. She is married with two children who are still living at home and her husband is a farmer. Sors typically makes about 3 USD daily. She is requesting a loan of 1,000 USD to purchase farmland.

loans.use: to purchase land

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Esi M. is divorced and has a child. This picture shows her preparing kenkey, a fermented dough usually made from corn/maize and served with soup or vegetables. Esi works producing and selling kenkey at Abura. She uses her income to provide for the well-being of her family.

Esi is requesting a loan to purchase bags of maize to produce kenkey on a larger scale. With the profits from her expanded business, she plans to provide the best possible education for her child.

loans.use: the purchase bags of corn

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 39-year-old married man from Lebanon. He is the father of three school-aged children. He has almost fifteen years of experience working in construction. He is specialized in completing woodwork and cement projects. His business income is essentiA. to allow him to raise his three children and pay their school fees.  He works hard to be able to satisfy all their needs. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additionA. wood for his newest project. He has high hopes for the future of his business; he is looking to continue expansion of his business in the coming year. In the future, he plans to start working with some construction entrepreneurs in order to expand his business operation.

loans.use: to purchase additional wood for his newest project

loans.name: Tamara Urmanbetova Group

texts.en:
Tamara U. is the leader of this group. She is a 49-year-old widow who is a resident of Bokonbaevo, a nice village on the south coast of Isykul lake. She has two children who attend school. 

Four years ago, with the initial investment of 5,000 KGS, Tamara opened a kiosk near the hospital to sell convenience goods. She currently earns 6,000 KGS per month. With the money from her loan, Tamara will purchase goods for her store to increase turnover and expand her business. In the future, Tamara wants to purchase a vehicle in to decrease her transportation expenses.



--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious, and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase goods

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia K. is thirty-seven years old. She is single and has three children aged between twenty-one years old and eighteen years old. Her business is located at a busy market known as Kithyoko. She is served by the Thika branch. Thika is the region in Kenya known for production of pineapples. 

Patricia operates a restaurant in which she serves food to local people. She has been in this business for two years now and has two employees. She says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge she has is the rise in food prices, making it hard for her customers to buy her food. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy such food items as flour, rice, beans, maize and sugar to expand her business and meet the demand of her customers. In future, she hopes to open a hotel at Kithyoko. She also dreams of giving her children university education. She describes herself as patient, understanding and innovative.

loans.use: Flour, rice, beans, maize and sugar

loans.name: Abahujumugambi No 3 Group

texts.fr: Alexis Ntwarinyakagabo est agent de la pharmacie, et il est un membre du groupe Abahujumugambi.  Il  a 38 ans, il est marié, et il a 5 enfants entre 2 ans et 14 ans.  Trois de ses enfants vont à l’école.  Il va utiliser son prêt pour acheter de médicament, Maalox, et paracétamol pour son activité de pharmacie.  Sa stratégie pour la croissance de l’affaire est d’améliorer ses activités Professional pharmaceutique.  Il voudrait devenir grossiste, et pour la famille, il voudrait payer les frais scolaires pour ses enfants, et acheter d’une parcelle.
texts.en: Alexis Ntwarinyakagabo is a pharmaceuticals salesman and he is a member of the Abahujumugambi group. He is 38 years old, married and has five children between the ages of two and fourteen. Three of his children attend school. He is going to use his loan to buy medecines: Maalox and paracetamol for his pharmaceutical business. His strategy to expand his business is to improve his professional pharmaceutical activities. He would like to become a wholesaler, and with regard to his family, he would like to be able to pay his children's school fees and buy a piece of land.

loans.use: Purchase of medecines: Maalox and paracetamol for his pharmaceutical business,

loans.name: Khorn's Group

texts.en:
In Yea P'aeu village, Takeo province, this group consists of five people, applying for a group loan. Mrs. Khorn N. leads this group loan and she has been selected by the other group members. Each will use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their family's standards of living.

She and husband, Mr. Hul Some, are farmers who own a small piece of land. They grow rice to sell in order to support their family. Mr. Hul Some is also a fisherman. Currently, Mrs. Khorn N. has some problems because her field has infertile soil. There are a lot of insects and the land is far away from an irrigation system. To improve production, Mrs. Khorn N. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticides, and gasoline. She has one child who is too young yet to work or study.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticides, and gasoline.

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua B. sells fried and smoked fish at Abura. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a carpenter. Ekua has been in the fish business for thirty years. She assists her husband in taking care of the home. 

Her loan will be used to buy more fish to expand her business. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to buy a plot of land. Ekua is standing by the smoked fish.

loans.use: buy more fish to expand her business

loans.name: Mrs. Saroeurn Kung Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Saroeurn K. is a village bank president in Kampong Pou village, TaK. province. She has been selected by nine people who make up a village bank loan. Each portion of the loan can improve each group member's standard of living for their families. 

She is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare plot of land to grow rice. She sells the rice to support her family's living expenses while her husband, Mr. Yary Kun, is a palm juice collector. He also earns some money to support his family. They earn little money even though they try to work hard. So, to improve her family's living conditions, Mrs. Saroeurn K. is asking for a loan to add more money. She would like to buy a cow for breeding to start a new business. She is a mother of three children, one of whO. is a driver who earns a low salary while the others are attending the local public school.

loans.use: To buy a cow.

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena K. is married and has three children. Her husband is a teacher. Abena sells porridge made from millet. She often serves her porridge with bread, milk and sugar at Abura. She assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. She is asking for the loan to purchase more ingredients to prepare porridge for sale.  She plans to reinvest her profit back into her business.

At the time this picture was taken, Abena had finished selling the bread and is demonstrating how she pours the millet porridge into polythene bags for her customers.

loans.use: purchase more ingredients to prepare porridge for sale

loans.name: Mary Njeri

texts.en:
Mary  is 35 years old. She is married to John Murage, who contributes to the family's income. She runs a dairy farm which has been in operation for a period of 14 years. The farm brings in an income of about KES 7,000.

She is taking her first loan from KADET LTD to buy an extra dairy cow in order to increase productivity. She hopes to become a leading dairy farmer in her region and to give her children a quality education and improve their living standards.

loans.use: To buy an extra dairy cow.

loans.name: Araba

texts.en:
Araba T. prepares 'Fante kenkey' (fermented maize dough) at Abura.  She is married to a driver. Demand for the 'kenkey' is increasing and so she is asking for the loan  to purchase more maize to prepare' kenkey' for sale. She assists her husband in taking care of the home. She anticipates using the new profit from her business to buy a plot of land.

This photo shows Araba in the process of preparing the 'kenkey' she sells.

loans.use: purchase more maize to prepare the 'kenkey' for sale

loans.name: Sadiya's Group

texts.en:
Sadiya S., the leader of this group, is a resident of Bokonbaevo, a nice village on the south coast of Isykul lake. Sadiya, 59, is married to a retiree who receives a monthly pension of 2500 soms. Sadiya herself works as a schoolteacher. Five years ago, with an initial investment of 3000 soms, the family started to breed livestock. Reselling some animals after fattening, they earn 4200 soms per month. With the loan, Sadiya wants to purchase hay for the cattle. In the future she plans to start house repairing.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase hay

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 50-year-old married man and the father of three children. He is from Lebanon. He started working in the agriculture field 35 years ago and started his own business in 1980. He cultivates vegetables and olives. He delivers his harvest to a local agriculture market. He is the main income provider of his family but two of his children help him with the household expenses. One of the children is an employee and the other works as a blacksmith. Today he is requesting to borrow $700 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase agriculture tools and supplies to increase his productivity and, therefore, his income. He works hard and hopes to reach a better level in his life by expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase agriculture tools and supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine and to expand his business

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace T. is married and has two children. Her husband works in construction. Grace has been selling cooked rice and sweet potatoes at Abura  for three years. Grace assists her husband in feeding, clothing and educating her children. More sweet potatoes are demanded by her customers and so she is asking to use the loan to purchase more to expand her business. She plans to reinvest the additional income back into her business.

loans.use: To purchase more sweet potatoes to cook for sale

loans.name: Eina

texts.en:
Eina is a mother of one two-year-old son, Khalil, and married to Nael. Eina's husband has a workshop where he fixes and performs maintenance for cars. Eina's husband wants to replace some of the tools he uses and buy some necessary ones.

Eina is an employee and her salary with the husband's income is enough to cover all family expenses.

Eina's husband Nael appears in the picture here as she is a conservative woman, as are many Gaza inhabitants.

loans.use: To purchase auto repair tools

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy all the necessities for the wedding party

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama A. is married and takes care of four children. She assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Ama sells cooked rice and serves it with tomato sauce at Abura. She . Her business just started some months ago. She wants to expand the business with the loan she hopes to get. Ama will use the loan to buy more rice and other ingredients to cook for sale.  She hopes to reinvest the new profits.

loans.use: She will use the loan to buy more rice and other ingredients to cook for sale.

loans.name: Gulay

texts.en:
Gulay B. is a 58 year-old villager who lives in Blagveshenka village, in the south of Kyrgyzstan. She is married and has four sons and two daughters.  After finishing school, she got married and with her husband started to work for a state farm. The breakdown of the Soviet Union gave this couple the opportunity to start their own business. Thanks to Gulay’s wide experience in cultivating cotton and her responsible and precise attitude with this activity, she managed to broaden her business by purchasing livestock. Currently she breeds three cows and four sheep and also cultivates 1,300 hectare of land. 

Gulay is a reliable Bai-Tushum borrower who repaid her first loan without any delay and used it as intended. Now Gulay needs a loan of 80,000 Kyrgyz Soms to purchase cattle, which will allow her to expand her farm. With the revenues from the business, she plans to build a barn for her livestock and hold her son’s marriage. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Nataliya's Group

texts.en:
Nataliya F., 31, is the resident of Kant, a small town near to Bishkek (capital of Kyrgyzstan).  She is the leader of this group. Nataliya is married to a builder. Together they are bringing up three sons. The two older sons are at school but the third is not old enough yet.  Nataliya herself works in a bakery. Four years ago with the initial investment of 7000 soms the family started to breed cattle.By  reselling cattle after fattening them they earn extra money to cover their family expenses.  With money received from the loan, Nataliya wants to purchase more cattle for breeding.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama A. is married and has two children. Her husband is a mason. For the past four years, Ama has been selling cassava, plantain, and banku (fermented corn or cassava dough) with fried fish at Abura. Ama’s work income assists her husband to provide for the basic needs of the family.

Ama is requesting a loan to increase the capital for her business. She will buy more corn to prepare banku and purchase fresh fish to be fried for sale. Ama will use the profits from her business to educate her children. 

In this photo, Ama has a ladle in the corn dough mixture to be cooked into banku. She is also showing the fish she will be frying to serve with the banku.

loans.use: to buy corn and fresh fish

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Esi O. is a widow. For the past 15 years, she has prepared doughnuts at Abura. Esi uses her income to provide for her own well-being. She will use her loan to purchase ingredients to prepare doughnuts to better supply her customers. Esi plans to reinvest the profits from her loan into expanding her business.
 
In this picture, Esi is displaying some of the ingredients and cookware she uses to prepare doughnuts.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients to prepare doughnuts

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Esi E. is married and has two children. Her husband is a cleaner. Esi produces and sells Fante kenkey (fermented dough usually made from corn/maize and served with soup or vegetables) at Abura. The profits from her kenkey business are used to educate her children and as a way of assisting her husband.  

Esi will use her loan to purchase maize to prepare kenkey for distribution to her customers. With the profits from her expanded business, Esi plans to provide a meaningful education for her children.

loans.use: to purchase corn

loans.name: Gulzat's Group

texts.en:
Gulzat J., 34, leads this loan group and lives in Kadamjai, a small town in the southern part of Kyrgyzstan. For the last 15 years, she has made a living by taking orders for, and sewing, Kyrgyz national dress and blankets. In a typical month, she earns 4,000 soms, an income which has allowed her to save enough money to buy a one-room flat.  She has applied for this loan to buy the fabrics and materials she needs to continue her business. In the future, she hopes to save enough money to open her own sewing workshop.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to buy fabrics and materials

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 38-year-old married man and the father of three school-age children. He is from Lebanon. He has been working in the construction field for the past 15 years. His work consists of wall foliage. He has been involved in this occupation for 15 years. He works closely with construction entrepreneurs where he completes the concrete effort. Today, he is requesting to borrow $800 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additional wood for his newest project.

loans.use: To purchase additional wood

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama E. makes a living selling cassava, plantain, vegetables and other food items at a local market. She has four children, is married to a taxi driver and uses her income to help her husband pay school fees and utility bills. She will use her loan to buy more food to sell and continue expanding her business. Ama hopes to use the additional profits made possible by this loan to build a shop where she can sell her goods.

loans.use: To buy more food to sell to her customers

loans.name: Tamer

texts.en:
Tamer is 21 years old and from Gaza, a city in the Gaza Strip. Tamer is a minibus driver. He started driving the bus two years ago, transporting passengers inside the city of Gaza and now he is transporting passengers between the five cities in the Gaza Strip.

Tamer came to FATEN for a loan to pay for the bus maintenance, which it needs. Maintaining the bus will make it possible for Tamer to work longer hours and increase his income.

Tamer appears in the picture above next to his bus.

loans.use: To pay for bus maintenance

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 39-year-old married man. He is from Lebanon. He has owned a mini-market since 2000 and has 12 years of experience in the same field.  He offers daily used products to his customers. He is the only income source for his family. He is willing to expand his business so that he can increase his income and have a better lifestyle. Today, he is requesting $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additional products for his grocery store, such as food products, dairy products, and detergents. He purchases the products from a wholesale local commercial center. It is very common in Lebanon to find small supermarkets selling perishable and non-perishable goods. As members of the communities themselves, storeowners have a deep understanding of local consumer needs and can offer products that meet local demands. The strong network of community relationships are an important component of life in Lebanon, especially in smaller towns and villages.

loans.use: To purchase additional products for his grocery store

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi A. is married, responsible for the support of five people and earns a living by making and selling kenkey, a dumpling made of corn husks that is very popular in the Accra region of Ghana. Her husband makes a living as a farmer. Esi uses her income to help her husband run and maintain their home. She has applied for a loan to buy ingredients to make more keneky, and eventually hopes to purchase her own farm. In this photo, we see Esi holding a sample of the corn dough she uses to make kenkey, and in the nearby sack we see the corn husk from which she makes her dough.

loans.use: To buy maize to make kenkey to sell to her customers

loans.name: Margret

texts.en: Margret is 43 years old, married, has six children and lives in her own home in Kasese, Uganda. For the last 20 years, she has run a beauty salon where she shapes and treats hair. Her goal is to have the most popular salon in town, and she has applied for a loan to make this possible by buying a hair dryer and more of the beauty products she uses in her business.

loans.use: To buy a hair dryer and beauty products for her salon

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi A. P. makes a living selling clothing and fruits in the town of Abura. She has three children and her husband is employed as a security guard. She and her husband work hard to meet the needs of their children, and she is applying for this loan to buy more fruit to sell to her customers. She hopes to use the additional income made possible by this loan to build a store in which she can sell her products.

loans.use: To buy more fruits to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy the construction supplies

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua K. sells roasted maize mixed with groundnuts, cloth and cassava in Abura. Ekua has received a junior-high education. She is divorced and has two children. She has been in this trade for seven years. 

The loan she is requesting will be used to buy cloth to expand her business. She sees to the well-being of the family. The profits that will be acquired as a result of the loan will be used to pay the school fees of her children.

loans.use: The loan she is requesting  will be used to buy cloth to expand her business

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is a 35-year-old married male with nine children. He owns a house in Kasese, Uganda, and his vision is to educate his children. 

He has been dealing in retail items for 10 years. He started with capital of 140,000 Uganda shillings and now has increased that to 7,000,000 Uganda shillings. Samuel needs the loan to buy sugar, cement, rice and soap for selling.

loans.use: Buying sugar, cement, rice and soap

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama K. is married to a mason and has five dependents. Ama sells dresses and also cooks banku (cornmeal dish) and serves it with soup at Abura. Ama uses her income to assist her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Ama will use the loan to purchase ingredients to prepare the food for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Ama plans put up a better structure where she can sell her food.

On her left hand in this photo is a pot of palm nut. The pot on fire has the banku in it which she is stirring.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients to prepare food for sale.

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en: Lilian is a thirty year old single mother of two children, who rents a house in Kasese, Uganda. She has been dealing in a clothing business and operating a bar for two years amidst hardships of high rent and debtors who take a long time to pay. Her vision is a wholesale business and building a house. Lillian needs the loan to buy clothes for sale.

loans.use: To buy clothes for sale.

loans.name: Cruz Azul Group

texts.es:
El comité “Cruz Azul” inicia ciclo  con la Fundación Paraguaya , la mayoría de sus integrantes ya  realiza actividades productivas, pero incluyen entre sus integrantes a  señoras que emprenderán actividades. 
Anhelan un futuro mejor para sus hijos es por eso que se esfuerzan el doble para facilitarles los materiales para su desarrollo y formación.   
Asi una de las integrantes es  la señora Cynthia quien se  dedica a la venta de  ropas.
Ella decidio en  esta oportunidad optar por este negocio para ya que es la temporada  de mucha venta de ropas por la fiestas que se acercan.
Quiere contar con buena variedad y cantidad para ofrecer  y poder competir con los demas  negocios.
Para ella solicita el pretamo para la compra de remeras, camisillas, vestidos, y otras prendas de vestir de la temporada.
texts.en:
The group named "Cruz Azul" has started a loan cycle with Fundacion Paraguaya (Kiva Field Partner). The majority of the members already have viable businesses but there are a few members who will be just starting up their businesses.

They strive towards a better future for their kids, and they have been working twice as hard to provide them with the support they need for their develpment and education. 

One of the members is Cynthia and she has a retail clothing business. 

She decided to opt in to this business opportunity to take advantage of the season when clothing sales are high, for the holidays that are approaching.

She wants to have a good variety and quantity of clothing to resell, to be in good shape to compete with the other businesses.  To this end she requests a loan and she will purchase t-shirts, tank tops, dresses, and other items of clothing suitable for the season.

loans.use: To purchase t-shirts, shorts dresses, tank tops and other items of clothing for the season.

loans.name: Aba

texts.en: Aba A. is married to a mason and together they live with their two children. She sells provisions and fruits at Abura. Aba uses her income to assist her husband in the general upkeep of the home. She will use the loan to increase the supply of provisions to expand her business. With the new profits from her expanded business, Aba plans educate her children.

loans.use: To increase the supply of provisions to expand her business.

loans.name: Aba

texts.en: Aba A. is married and has two children. Her husband is a carpenter. She has been a junior high education, and is a seamstress at Abura. She has been in this business for ten years. Aba uses her income to assist her husband in the general upkeep of the home. Aba will use the loan to purchase more material to expand her sewing business. With the new profits from her expanded business, Aba plans to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase more material to expand her sewing business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy onions.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis B. O. is a married man. His wife helps in the home and they have two children aged four years old and two years old whom they hope to give a good education to the university level. His business is located at Kakamega. Kakamega is the region in Kenya known for production of sugar cane and it is known as the sugar belt region. He sells polythene bags to the local people. He has been in this business for four years now. Besides this business, he also farms vegetables and sells them to augment his income.

He says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge he has is getting many customers in some areas. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 70,000 to buy more polythene bags to grow his business. He hopes to grow his business to a wholesale one. He describes himself as hardworking, polite to customers, and ambitious.

loans.use: To buy polythene bags.

loans.name: Apollonea

texts.en:
Apollonea A. is a married lady. Her husband helps in running the business and they have six children aged between twenty-five years old and twelve years old. Her business is located at a busy market in Kakamega. Kakamega is the region in Kenya known for production of sugar cane and it is known as the sugar belt region.

She makes and sells steel doors, windows and gates. She has been in this business for five years now and has two employees. She says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge she has is scarcity of materials for making the items that she sells. She also admits that being a woman, she has to work extra hard to convince the local people that she can do exellent work for them just like men. This is because this kind of business is male dominated. She works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 50,000 to buy steel to expand her business and meet the demands of her customers. In future, she hopes to open a hardware store. She also hopes to bring up a healthy and literate family. She describes herself as hardworking, persistent and patient.

loans.use: To buy steel.

loans.name: Leah

texts.en:
Leah T. L. is thirty-four years old. She is married and has one child aged twelve years old, whom they hope to give a good education up to the university level. Her business is located at a busy market in Kakamega. Kakamega is the region in Kenya known for production of sugar cane and it is known as the sugar belt region.

She has a boutique in which she sells children's wear and women's dresses. She has been in this business for five years now. She says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge she has is that there are many people in the area doing the same kind of business as hers, hence customers are spoiled for choice. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 49,000 to buy more clothes to expand her business and meet the demands of her customers, especially during this festive season. In future, she hopes to open a bigger boutique. She describes herself as an ambitious lady.

loans.use: To buy clothes.

loans.name: Unidas Group

texts.es:
El Comité de Mujeres de nombre Unidas, se conformó con mucho esfuerzo y esmero  en forma conjunta y solidaria dentro del programa. 
Además del trabajo independiente de cada una, también desarrollan actividades en forma conjunta  para recaudar fondos con el fin de contar con un capital dentro del grupo, a la vez se ayudan mutuamente para llegar a los objetivos que es la de trabajar para apoyar económicamente  a sus familias en especial. 
Una de las integrantes es la señora Ana quien se dedica a la venta frutas y verduras. 
Ella es muy mujer muy trabajadora que lucha por su familia y por su bienestar para salir adelante. 
Se encuentra muy satisfecha con su grupo ya que pudo conseguir muchas a través de la misma.
Actualmente solicita el préstamo para la compra de frutas y verduras.
texts.en:
The 'Unidas' (United) Women's Committee was established with a lot of hard work and care.  It works in a united and supportive way within the program.

As well as the independent work of each committee member, the members also work in a united way to make funds so that they have some capital within the group.  They also help each other to achieve their goals.  Their main goal is to work so that they can financially support their families.

One of the committee's members is Ana who sells fruit and vegetables.  She is a very hard-working woman who works hard for her family and their well-being.  She works hard to get them ahead in life.  She is very happy with her group since, through it, she has managed to achieve a lot.

Ana is requesting this loan to buy fruit and vegetables.

loans.use: To buy fruit and vegetables

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose D. is currently in the business of selling onions, sugar, tomatoes, beans, rice, and passion fruits, and is requesting a loan to stock more of these items to sell. Rose is 23 years old and is married to a carpenter. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy domestic animals like chickens, goats, and sheep, to raise at home.

loans.use: To stock more onions, tomatoes, rice, passion fruits, etc. to sell.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose N. is 45 years old, married, and has four children.  For 26 years, she has been doing tailoring in Kasawo-Kayunga.  Rose began her tailoring business after she received apprentice tailoring training at a tailoring school in the metropolis of Mukono. She sells most of the clothes she sews. School uniforms are her major specialty though she does not limit herself to only that. Rose also has a side soft drinks and pig husbandry business. These have provided supplemental income.  Her monthly profits are 700,000 shillings. With this loan, Rose is going to buy more cloth-making textile fabrics.

loans.use: To purchase more cloth-making textile materials

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 49 ans, 5 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Klacouma, préfecture de Dioïla ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce des céréales.                                                                                     
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi sont à leur dixième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter des grains de céréales uniquement.                                                                          
FANTA D., qui est la présidente du groupe s’approvisionne en grains de céréales sur place dans le village et au marché de Massigui. Elle effectue ses ventes sur place, au marché de Massigui, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour payer le prêt, prendre en charge de façon complémentaire les dépenses familiales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the group named Benkadi are all married and they have an average age of 49. They each have 5 children and they live in large traditional families in the village of Klacouma, a dsitrict of Dioila in the region of Koulikoro (the second administrative region in the Republic of Mali). 

They know each other through family relations and their business is the sale of cereal grains.

The women of the Benkadi group are on their tenth loan cycle and it will be used exclusively to purchase cereal grians.

Fanta D. is the leader of the group. She purchases grains for resale in the village and in the market in Massigui.  She makes her sales in the village and in the market in Massigui, completing the sale in either cash or credit. Her client base is made up of both men and women. 

She expects to make a monthly profit of 15000 FCFA which will be used to repay the loan, to pay for the family's expenses, and to reinvest back into her business.

loans.use: To purchase cereal grains.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose T. is currently in the business of selling mixed goods like tomatoes, beans, and maize flour, and is requesting a loan to stock more maize flour to sell. Rose is 23 years old and is married to a peasant. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

loans.use: To stock more bags of maize flour to sell.

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en:
Adjoa A. prepares kenkey (sourdough dumplings) at Abura. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a famer, and she assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Demand for her goods is high and she is looking to expand her business. She will use the loan to purchase more maize to prepare more kenkey for sale. She hopes to reinvest her additional capital.

Adjoa at the time of visit had not processed the maize into dough to be used, and she is showing the soaked maize she would be using for the kenkey.

loans.use: To purchase more maize to prepare more kenkey for sale.

loans.name: Joya

texts.en: Joya D. is currently in the business of operating a restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more food stuffs in her restaurant. Joya is 34 years old and is married to a mechanical engineer. She has 6 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: To stock more food stuffs in her restaurant.

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Esi A. is married and has one child. Her husband is a teacher. She has received a junior high education. Esi sells cassava and plantain at Abura, and assists her husband in providing the basic needs of the home. Esi will use the loan to purchase more of her food stuffs for sale to expand her business. With the new profits from her expanded business, Esi plans to save towards the education of her child.

The sacks around her are full of cassava.

loans.use: To purchase more of her food stuffs for sale.

loans.name: Heart Of Jesus Group

texts.es:
|Es  un comité conformada por 10 mujeres de  Ybycui, todas ellas se encuentran trabajando en distintas areas del negocio,  son un grupo que ya tienen experiencia en trabajo de  grupo.
La presidenta es la señora Amelia M., vienen preparando milanesa para la venta, el resto de los miembros vienen realizando actividades similares a esta, el grupo tienen la intencion de crecer y agradecen la oportunidad  brindada por la fundacion Paraguaya.
La señora Amelia quiere preparar gran cantidad de comestibles y salir a vender y salir a vender ya que hay mucha concuerrencia de gente por el centro de la ciudad.
Solicita el préstamo para la compra de carne para la preparación de comestibles.
texts.en:
This group is made up of 10 women from the community of Ybycui. They all work in various business types. They have all worked in groups before. 

The leader of the group is Amelia M.. She makes hamburger patties for sale. The rest of the members carry out similar businesses to this one. The group's intention is to grow and expand the community that has come together thanks to Fundacion Paraguaya (Kiva Field Partner). 

Amelia wants to prepare a large quantity of prepared foods to sell in the downtown area of the city for the great number of visitors.

She requests a loan to purchase meat to prepare her foods.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary S. is currently in the business of operating a restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more food stuffs in her restaurant like rice, sugar, meat, onions, fish, etc. Mary is 28 years old, divorced, and has 2 children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: To stock more food stuffs in her restaurant like rice, sugar, meat, onions, fish, etc.

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua E. operates a food joint at Abura. Ekua has received a junior high education, is married, and has four children. Her husband is a mason, and she assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be enable her to increase her capital to expand her business. She will use the loan to purchase more food stuffs and ingredients to prepare food for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate her children. 

In this picture, Ekua is stirring the soup she had made.

loans.use: To purchase more food stuffs and ingredients to prepare food for sale.

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en: Jackline A. is currently in the business of selling daga fish and other types of fish and is requesting a loan to stock more fish to sell. Jackline is 30 years old, divorced, and has 3 children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a motor bike which will be used to operate a boda boda business to generate more money.

loans.use: To stock more fish to sell.

loans.name: Jessica Milagros Group

texts.es:
El Comité de Mujeres de nombre Jessica Milagros, se conformó en fecha 28 de abril del 2010, gracias a la Sra. Ramona P., quien es integrante de otro grupo y le comentó a su sobrina sobre la forma de trabajo en el grupo, quien quedo muy interesada y decidió conformar su grupo, invito a sus vecinas y  contactaron con la asesora, y conformaron el comité con 14 mujeres   que se encuentran trabajando ya en el 2do. Ciclo, en forma conjunta y solidaria dentro del programa.
Es un excelente grupo gracias al  trabajo solidario realizado y continúan trabajando con el programa hasta estos días.
El crédito retirado por cada integrante va destinado para diferentes actividades tales como venta de especies, venta de mercerías, venta de mercaderías, venta de prendas de vestir, venta de bebidas, venta de embutidos, venta de joyas, venta de carbón,   venta de helados,  venta de comestibles, venta de ropas, etc. 
Participan activamente en las reuniones semanales y tienen un trabajo solidario impecable.
Una de ellas es la señora Rosalba, quien se dedica a la venta de helados desde un negocio que ella posee en su casa. 
Comenta que actualmente cuenta con mucha venta por la temporada calurosa en Paraguay, y quiere contar con gran cantidad de helados.
Para su proyecto ella desea compra otra conservadora de helados para lo que solicita el préstamo.
texts.en:
The Jessica Milagros Women’s Committee was formed on April 28, 2010 thanks to Mrs. Ramona P.. Mrs. P., the organizer of another group, spoke about working with a group to her niece, who then was very interested. She decided to form this group and invited women from her neighborhood. They contacted the advisor and formed their committee with 14 members. They are now in their second loan cycle, working together with solidarity.  It is an excellent group, thanks to their hard work and solidarity, which continues to this day. 

This loan will be used by the women for their various activities, which include sales of spices, notions, groceries, dresses, soft drinks, cured meats, jewelry, charcoal, ice cream, fuel, clothing, etc. They have weekly meetings and work together very well.

One group member is Rosalba, who sells ice cream from a store in her home. She says that sales are very good right now because of the hot season in Paraguay, and she wants to continue to sell a large quantity of ice cream. She will use her portion of this loan to buy a new freezer for her business.

loans.use: Buy a freezer for ice cream

loans.name: Wycliffe

texts.en:
Wycliffe E. A. is a married man. His wife takes care of the household chores and they have three children aged between six years old and one year old. His business is located at Kakamega. Kakamega is the region in Kenya known for production of sugar cane and it is known as the sugar belt region.

He offers transport services to new and repeat customers. He has been in this business for two years now. He says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge he has is that the business is risky, especially at night when providing transport services to new customers. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 50,000 to buy spare parts to repare his motorbike and ensure it is in good condition to carry out business. He hopes to buy more motorbikes in future to expand his business. He also hopes to give his children quality education to the university level. He describes himself as patient, polite and ambitious.

loans.use: To buy spare parts.

loans.name: Edison

texts.es:
El Sr. Edison tiene 24 años de edad, vive en casa de sus padres en CONAVI La Esperanza. Él se dedica a la venta de joyas, ropas, CD y DVD  por la ciudad de Itá, dicha actividad lo viene realizando desde el año 2005. Cuenta que el negocio le va muy  bien por la clientela que ya formó gracias a los préstamos realizados en la fundación.
Su objetivo es ir creciendo como comerciante para así lograr todos sus metas propuestas.
El crédito que está solicitando es para la compra de mercaderías ya que en estas épocas tiene la mayor demanda de las mismas.
texts.en:
Edison is 24 years old. He lives with his parents in CONAVI La Esperanza. He sells jewellery, clothing, CDs and DVDs around the city of Itá. He has been doing it since 2005. He explains that the business is doing very well because of the customer base generated thanks to previous loans arranged through Fundación Paraguaya.

His aim is to continue to grow his trading activity so as to achieve all of his goals.

The loan he is requesting is to purchase different goods for which there is a greater demand this time of the year.

loans.use: Buy jewellery, clothing, CDs and DVDs.

loans.name: Twegatte Association-Jinja Group

texts.en: The spokesman for this group, 31 year old Paul I., has a story similar to many of the members of the Twegatte Association-Jinja group. Paul has had his farming business for three years in Jinja. He mostly sells crops, such as maize and beans, which he harvests from his gardens. Paul says he started out as a small scale farmer and later worked in a motorcycle transportation business, commonly referred to in Uganda as Boda Boda. His modest success in business he says all boils down to one thing - hard work. Paul's weekly business profits add up to 70,000 shillings. He is happily married with three kids. Paul will use this loan to procure more bags of the aforementioned crops. He says he is also going to use some of the proceeds to improve his farming gardens and to buy goats.

loans.use: The procurement of more maize and beans for resell, manure for his gardens and goats.

loans.name: Abishyizehamwe Abacuruzi Group

texts.fr: Jean Bosco N. est commerçant du riz, et il est un membre du groupe Abishyizehamwe Abacuruzi.  Il a 28 ans, il est marié, et il a 1 enfant qui a 2 ans.  Il a fini 6 ans d’école primaire.  Il va utiliser son prêt pour acheter de riz pour le vendre.  Sa stratégie pour la croissance de l’affaire est d’améliorer ses activités de commerce.  Il voudrait devenir grossiste, payer les frais scolaires pour ses enfants, acheter une parcelle, et payer les frais médicaux.
texts.en:
Jean Bosco N. sells rice. He is a member of the Abishyizehamwe Abacuruzi group. He is 28 years old, married, and has a 2-year-old child. He completed six years of primary school. 

He will use his loan to buy rice, which he will then sell. His business growth strategy is to improve his commercial activities. He wants to become a wholesaler, pay his children’s tuition fees, purchase a plot of land, and pay the medical expenses.

loans.use: Purchase of rice

loans.name: Kuña Aty Joayhu Group

texts.es:
El Comité de Mujeres de nombre Kuña Aty Joayhu, se conformo en fecha 19 de julio del 2.010, gracias a que la Directora de Finanzas, la Sra.  Nancy M. quien convenció a algunas compañeras que ya habían formado parte de otro grupo, a formar un nuevos grupo, luego contactaron con la asesora para la conformación del Comité.
En estos momentos se encuentran en el  2° ciclo, está conformado por 15 integrantes, las mismas reconocen la importancia de acceder a préstamos con la sólo presentación de  la cédula de identidad, y siendo la única condición de trabajar  unidas para fortalecer la solidaridad entre ellas.  
Todas ellas realizan actividades para recaudar fondos, se ayudan mutuamente para llegar a los objetivos en común que todas tienen dentro del grupo y con la Fundación Paraguaya.
Participan activamente en las reuniones semanales y tienen un trabajo solidario impecable.
Una de las integrantes es la señora Veneranda quien se dedica a la venta de ropas y se encuentra trabajando mucho por la temporada de mucha venta. Es una señora muy trabajadora y con la de sus ropas ella prepara y ofrece varios productos como comestibles y frutas y se siente contenta con su negocio.
Ella solicita el préstamo para la compra de ropas de diferentes modelos como remeras, camisillas, shorts, calzados para verano y otros.
texts.en:
The Kuña Aty Joayhu Women's Committee was formed on July 19th 2010 by the Financial Director Mrs Nancy M. who convinced some friends who had already formed part of another group to form a new group.  They then contacted their advisor who authorized the committee.

The committee are now in their second loan cycle and their group has 15 members.  They recognize the importance of being able to access loans simply by presenting their ID card with the only condition being that they will work together to strengthen the solidarity between them.

All of the women carry out business activities to make funds, they help each other to reach the common goals that they all have within the group and with Fundación Paraguaya.  They take an active part in the weekly meetings and work together impeccably.

One of the members of this group is Veneranda who sells clothes.  She is working a lot right now because this is a season when she makes a lot of sales.  Veneranda is a very hard-working woman.  As well as selling clothes, she also sells other products such as food and fruit.  She feels very happy with her business.  She is requesting a loan so that she can buy different kinds of clothes such as t-shirts, tops, shorts, summer footwear, etc.

loans.use: To buy clothes such as t-shirts, shorts, dresses and footwear

loans.name: Namaganga Women's Group-Jinja

texts.en: 53 year old David K. belongs to Namaganga Women's group-Jinja. For the last 6 years he has been a retailer in the Namaganga trading center-Jinja. To start his retail business, David used his savings from his old sugar cane business. Due to his ambition, he decided he wanted to enter into another business and his preference was retail. David, who is happily married with 7 kids, says his retail business generates 150,000 shillings per month. With this loan, David says he is going to purchase more retail general merchandise to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more general merchandise retail stock for resale.

loans.name: Claudia Jesus

texts.es:
L. socia pertenece al banco comunal “QORICHUSPA”; Este banco está ubicado en el distrito D. Huanchac en L. provincia y departamento D. Cusco.

L. socia es L. Sra: Claudia; elL. tiene  45 años. L. socia es casada, y tiene 2 hijos;  L. socia se dedica a L. compra D. artículos, L. socia compra al por mayor todo tipo D. artículos D. navidad como árboles, cintas decorativas, adornos naviD.ños, también venD. artículos para año nuevo y L. víspera D. enero y sus fiestas en L. provincia, L. socia ya tiene almacenado unos artículos pero le falta concluir el pago D. estos, L. socia también se dedica a L. agricultura, elL. tiene unos terrenos D. agricultura para producri maíz,L. socia desea el crédito para terminar D. pagar el envío D. L. campaña naviD.ña y L. mitad que debe a sus proveedores D. productos naviD.ños en esta ocación. L. socia solicita el préstamo para pagar a los proveedores D. L. campaña naviD.ña.

L. socia está feliz con el préstamo otorgado y se compromete a cumplir con el pago D. sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Claudia belongs to the Qorichuspa Communal Bank.  This bank is located in the Huanchac district of the Cusco province and department.

Claudia is 45 years old.  She is married and has two children.  She buys wholesale all types of Christmas items like trees, decorative ribbons, and Christmas ornaments.  She also sells merchandise for the New Year, New Year’s eve, and provincial fiestas.  She already has some merchandise, but she has not finished paying for it.

She is also a farmer.  She has some farming land, and she grows corn.

She wants the loan to finish paying for an order for the Christmas season and to pay her providers for Christmas products.  She is requesting the loan to pay the providers for Christmas merchandise.

She is happy with the loan she was granted, and she pledges to make her payments on time.

loans.use: To pay her providers for the Christmas season

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy sewing materials to sew dresses for her customers.

loans.name: Aditza Maria

texts.es:
Aditza es una pequeña comerciante de venta de ropa interior, desde hace varios años, logro invertir en ropa, Ventas que hace ambulante, y que gracias a su empeño y apoyo de la institución ha incrementado la variedad de sus ventas. Trabajo que hace para apoyar  a su familia.
Cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo quien labora en servicios de seguridad. Con este nuevo préstamo comprara: bóxer de varón y mujer, viquines, blúmer de niña, cosméticos, licras, entre otros productos que ayuden a aumentar sus ganancias.
Hoy en día está contenta porque gracias a los financiamientos, sus niveles de venta aumentaron al ofrecer más variedad en sus mercaderías.
texts.en:
Aditza is a small businesswoman who sells underwear.  She has been selling clothes for several years.  She makes her sales as an itinerant street vendor and, thanks to her hard work and the support of our institution, she has increased the range of her sales.  She works to support her family.  Aditza has the support of her husband who works in security services.

Aditza will use this new loan to buy men's boxer shorts, women's boy shorts, bikinis, girls' underpants, cosmetics, leggings and other products that will help to increase her profits.

Aditza is happy because, thanks to these loans, her sales levels have risen as she has been able to offer a greater variety of merchandise.

loans.use: To buy a variety of underwear, cosmetics and costume jewelry to improve her sales

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more maize for kenkey business.

loans.name: Irma Oneida

texts.es:
Irma de 50 años, es una mujer trabajadora que con dedicación y ayuda de una de su hija ahora tiene un cibercafé. Viviendo en una zona urbana llamada Guasmo ha trabajado para mantener a su familia ya que es madre soltera. 

Trabaja en el cyber con ayuda de su hija desde muy temprano. Los servicios que dan son de internet por hora, impresiones, escáner, venta de Cd y vende. También tiene un negocio de venta de comida en donde vende platos con carnes, pollo, pescados etc. 

Irma tiene mucha fe para que sus negocios prosperen y así poder mantener a su familia aunque le es difícil trabajar con competencias de comidas en el sector sigue trabajando. Quiere con el préstamo comprar una computadora e impresoras para su negocio del cyber. Uno de sus objetivos para el futuro es agrandar el cyber.
texts.en:
Irma is 50 years old.  She is a hard-working woman who, through her own hard work and the help of one of her daughters, now has an Internet cafe.  Irma lives in Guasmo and works to support her family as she is a single mother.

Irma works in her Internet cafe, with her daughter's help, from very early in the morning.  The services she provides are: Internet use by the hour, printing, scanning and CD sales.  She also has a food business and sells meat, chicken and fish dishes.

Irma has a lot of faith in her businesses doing well and being able to support her family.  Although it is difficult to work with the competition from other food businesses in the area, she continues to do so.  She would like to use this loan to buy a computer and printers for her Internet cafe business.  One of her goals for the future is to expand her Internet cafe.

loans.use: To buy a computer and printers

loans.name: Kuña Mbarete Group

texts.es:
El Comité de Mujeres de nombre Kuña Mbarete, se conformó en fecha 27 de julio del 2.010, mediante  una promoción realizada en la zona, a la Sra. Mirian F., quien quedo muy interesada y logro juntar a sus vecinas y amigas, luego contacto con la asesora para la formación del  grupo y  logró juntar a 16 mujeres quienes se encuentran trabajando muy a gusto en el 2º ciclo.
Participan activamente en las reuniones semanales, y están muy agradecidas con la Fundación Paraguaya.
Una de las integrantes es Maria Luisa, ella es una mujer joven estudiante, quien se dedica a la realización de trabajaos por computadoras desde su casa. Cuenta con un cartel que ofrece los servicios que ella realiza y constantemente recibe pedidos de trabajos prácticos para colegios y universidades y otros.
Comenta que su ingreso es bastante bueno y le ayuda mucho con sus gastos.
Solicita el préstamo para el pago por mantenimiento de su  computadora ya que su herramienta de trabajo principal.
texts.en:
The Kuña Mbarete Women's Committee was founded on July 27th 2010 as a result of promotional activities that were carried out in their area.  Mirian F. was very interested and managed to get together some neighbors and friends.
