loans.name: Efren

texts.en:
Efren T. is from the city of Tabid Ozamiz City. He is 28 years old. Efren is single and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Efren owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting seaweeds for sale. Efren has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Efren joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Efren is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Efren from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Caridad

texts.en:
Caridad S. is a 54-year-old, married woman from the city of Tabid Ozamiz City. Caridad and her husband have five adult-age children. To earn a living, Caridad owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector. Her primary source of income is derived from planting and harvesting seaweed for sale. Caridad has been engaged in this business for over 8 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2009, Caridad joined GDMPC to gain much-needed access to financial services. By doing so, she was better able to engage in business activities and to improve her family's standard of living. Recently, Caridad successfully repaid a prior loan in the amount of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. Caridad is now requesting a new loan, again in the amount of 7,000 PHP ($175), which will be used to expand her business. Notably, this loan would be the third loan taken out by Caridad from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business as a result of the loan to further improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte, and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is comprised of mostly of farmers, fishermen/women, and entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To continue to expand and improve her business

loans.name: Anarjan's Group

texts.en:
Anarjan M. is the leader of this group. She is the resident of Tashkomur, a small mining town in the south of Kyrgyzstan. She is 49 and married. Her husband is engaged in cattle breeding. 

Two years ago with the initial investment of 5,000 soms, Anarjan started to sell flour in the local market. She earns 9,300 soms per month. That profit made it possible for her to increase the number of cattle. 

Anarjan hopes to receive a loan because she needs money to purchase flour for sale. In the future she dreams to open her own store.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase flour for sale

loans.name: Ernis

texts.en:
Ernis K. is an attentive father of two daughters and one son. In accordance with Kyrgyz ancient tradition, Ernis, as the youngest son of his parents, lives with and takes care of his father. Their family is very tight knit, and all members of the family help and support each other. After graduating from transportation college, he started to work at the local police office, where he still works as a security officer.

Salaries in the public sector are low, however, so Ernis decided to start a cattle-breeding business. Using his starting capital in the amount of 10,000 KGS, Ernis bought three milk cows, whose milk Ernis’s wife sells at the local market. By doing so, they are able to provide their children with essential items and to pay for some of their family's living expenses.

Now, in order to increase his profits, Ernis is applying for a loan in the amount of 80,000 KGS ($1,725) to buy two more milk cows and feed for his livestock. In the future, Ernis dreams of establishing his own farm with a large number of cattle.

Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To expand his business by purchasing additional cattle and livestock feed

loans.name: Nurjamal's Group

texts.en:
Nurjamal A. is a resident of Kerben, a small town in the south of Kyrgyzstan.  She is the leader of this group. She is 39 and married to a driver. Together with her husband, they are bringing up two daughters, and both daughters are in school.  

Four years ago, with an initial investment of 5,000 soms, Nurjamal started to sell fruits and vegetables at the market. In this way she earns 7,000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, Nurjamal wants to purchase more fruits and vegetables in order to resell them at the higher price and make some profit.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Mwende

texts.en:
Mwende N. is a 49-year-old widow who runs a grocery store in the Mukuku area of Tala, Kenya. She has two children: Muoki (18 years old) and Ngina (14 years old and in the 8th grade). Mwende dreams of one day operating her very own wholesale shop. She describes herself as hardworking.

Mwende was introduced to KADET by the credit officer in charge of the Tala office. Mwende has been running this business for a period of 10 years and she typically earns a monthly profit of 6,000 KES. She is now seeking a loan in the amount of 15,000 KES, which would be her second loan from KADET. She plan to use the loan to buy fruits and vegetables (including kale, tomatoes, and onions) and other grocery items (such as sugar, tea leaves, and detergents) for her shop. If this loan serves to boost her business, then Mwende will use the additional profits to pay her children's school fees and to cover her children’s other living expenses.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional inventory

loans.name: Naumi Wayua

texts.en:
Naumi M. is 52 years old and married to Johnstone. They have four children. For the past 11 years, Naumi has been a commercial farmer. Her monthly income is 25,000 KES and her husband contributes to the family income.  

Naumi has successfully repaid previous KADET Ltd loans. This will be her fourth loan and she will use the money to buy fertilizer, potatoes, mangos, and onion seedlings. In the future, Naumi hopes to be a leading farmer and be able to provide a quality education for her children and improve her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, mangos, onion seedlings, and potatoes

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
Angelina P. is from the village of Santa Isabel. She is 50 years old. Angelina is married and has three adult children. 

To make a living, Angelina owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Angelina has been engaged in her business for more than six years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Angelina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Angelina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. Angelina is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Angelina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Analiza's Group

texts.en:
Analiza A. is from the village of Buena Suerte, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 36 years old. Analiza is the group leader of a seven-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Analiza is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Analiza owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Analiza has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Analiza joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Analiza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Analiza is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Analiza from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

The family has to spend USD 44 on food, USD 2 on electricity supply, and USD 21 on other necessary expenses every month. V. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.name: Noel Nkuchuk

texts.en:
Noel Nkuchuk is 27 and married to T. who is 37 years old. They have five children: Kelvin who is 15; Saroni who is 13; Naisoni who is 10; Momi who is three; and Jane who is one. All of the school-aged children attend school. For the past 10 years, Noel has been selling jewelry and textiles at the busy Kitengela market. Most of her customers are women from the area and her monthly profit is 5,000 KES. 

Noel was introduced to KADET by the credit officer in charge of the Kitengela office. She is requesting a loan of 80,000 KES to buy beads for making jewelry, purchase textiles, and pay for her children’s school fees. Noel describes herself as hardworking, and, if this loan boosts her business, she will save her profits. In the future, Noel dreams of becoming a prominent businesswoman.

loans.use: to buy beads, textiles, and pay school fees

loans.name: Peter Kamande

texts.en:
Peter Kamande is 30 years old and married to Florence Wanjiru, who contributes to the family income. They have three children. Peter has been running his motorcycle transport business for two years with an income of 3,700 Kenyan Shillings (Kshs) per month.

This is his second loan from KADET Ltd after successfully repaying the previous one. He hopes to buy a car for hire and to give his children a quality education and improve their living standards.

loans.use: To add to savings for the purchase of another motorbike.

loans.name: Albert

texts.en:
Albert G. is a married father of two children, aged seven and six years old, for whom he and his wife hope to provide a good education to the university level. His wife runs a grocery store, while Albert owns a motor bike and has been providing transport services to the local people of Mukuru Kwa Njenga for four years now. He says that this business is profitable, but his major challenge is competition from the many others offering similar transportation services. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well.

He is using his loan of Kes 50,000 to buy spare motor bike parts in preparation for a busy festive season. He also plans to stock their grocery store to increase their earnings during the Christmas season. Albert hopes to grow his business by purchasing more motor bikes and eventually vans for his business. He also sees himself building a nice house for his family. He describes himself as wise, aggressive and business-minded. Albert is served by the Kitengela branch.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts and vegetables

loans.name: Enhbat

texts.en:
Enhbat L. is 50 years old and lives with his wife and two children and one grandson in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. 

His oldest daughter works as a cook in the local cafe and his middle son attends university in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, while his wife stays at home taking care of her grandson. 

Enhbat operates a dried-meat-making and trading business in his town. He purchases livestock to make meat, cuts it in strips, dries it and and sells those dried meats at his local market during the spring and summer months. He began his business in 2008 and has gained significant experience as a businessman. He managed to establish himself in the business community and has gained many permanent customers within the short period.

Enhbat is requesting a 3600000 MNT loan in order to increase his working capital for his dried-meat-making business.

For the future, he plans to expand his business by puchasing a packaging machine for his meat production.

loans.use: To buy more meat for drying

loans.name: Micheal

texts.en:
Micheal is a 46-year-old hardworking married man living in a rented house in Fort Portal, Uganda. He is solely charged with the responsibility of looking after his family, and his mission is to educate his children up to university. 

He cuts people's grass for a living and has been in this business for five years now.  Michael needs the money to buy a machine for cutting grass. His business plan is to own at least three grass-cutting machines.

loans.use: To purchase a machine for cutting grass

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
It was five years ago when Elsa ventured into the fish-selling business. The idea of having this kind of business crossed her mind when her husband, who is a fisherman, had caught more fish than usual in the lake. Elsa sold those in their neighborhood and she realized that selling fish brought bigger profits faster than any other kind of business she had in recent years. 

Fish is salable because it is one of the most basic needs of human beings, especially for people who live in very remote areas of the province. They are far from the municipal markets. Thus buying from vendors who come to their community is very attractive. Also, more people choose to buy fish than meat because it is cheaper and healthier.

From then on, Elsa used her loan from ASHI in her fish-selling business. Out of the profit she made, she was able to invest in her home and support her family financially. 

She kept on borrowing from ASHI to keep her business growing. Now, she plans to use her newly received loan to increase the volume of fish she sells so that someday, out of her business profit, she will be able to invest more in her home. 

Being a 46-year-old woman, Elsa wants her children to have their own livelihood. She believes that her business is the only inheritance she can turn over to them.

loans.use: To increase the volume of fish she can sell

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en:
Harriet is a 30-year-old single mother of two children living in a rented house in Fort Portal, Uganda. Her dream is to set up a sustainable income-generating venture for her children. 

She operates a retail shop and has been in this kind of business for two years, reaping tangible profits. Her goal is to have a wholesale shop. 

Harriet needs the loan to buy salt, soap and soft drinks for selling.

loans.use: To buy salt, soap and soft drinks for selling

loans.name: Liezel

texts.en:
Liezel I., 32, is from Calabayan Ozamiz City. She is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Liezel owns and operates a motor transportation services business. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2007, Liezel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP and is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP to repair an existing vehicle in order to provide better services. This will be her fourth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair an existing vehicle in order to provide better services.

loans.name: Lynn

texts.en:
Lynn A., 27, is from Proper Langcangan, Oroquieta City. She is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Lynn owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling dry goods in the local community. Lynn has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Lynn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP and is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her fourth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is a 30-year-old ambitious single mother of two children living in a rented house in Fort Portal, Uganda. She has a desire to secure a sustainable income for her family. 

She has had a beauty salon for four years now, and the income generated has helped her to provide the basics to her family. Her vision is to own a beauty parlor in the next two years. Susan needs the credit to buy synthetic hair and cosmetics for the salon.

loans.use: Buying synthetic hair and chemicals for her salon

loans.name: Marlon

texts.en:
Marlon L., 45, is from Tinago Ozamiz City. He is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Marlon owns and operates a retail store selling used shoes (ukay-ukay) in the local community. He has been engaged in his business for over one year and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Marlon joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be his first loan from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Petrolina Nduge

texts.en:
Petronila is 37 years old and married to Munyuoki, who contributes to the family income. She has been running her green grocery store for 10 years, earning an income of approximately 18,000 Kenyan Shillings (Ksh) per month.

This is her third loan from KADET Ltd after successfully repaying the previous ones. She hopes to be a leading grocery supplier and to give her children a quality education and improve their living standards.

loans.use: To buy onions, vegetables and potatoes for resale.

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
As the saying goes, opportunity knocks only once. Arlene V., knows this truth and grabs every opportunity that comes her way. Arlene, 41, reached high school and is married to Rolando, a businessman. Together they are raising five children, of whom two are in elementary, one in high school, and the other two still staying at home. Together, they live in Pasay City, Philippines.

Arlene presently runs a sari-sari (variety) store, in which she sells items that are needed daily by neighbors in her community. Products on her shelves range from soap bars to candies and energy drinks to rice.  Having been at least ten years in business, she knows to pay her dues on time. She also has an excellent reputation with her fellow community partners in CCT* and, most importantly, her customers. Monthly she is able to earn a net income of Php 10,000.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a Php 50,000 loan. She intends to use this money to purchase more products for her store, all the more now that the Christmas season is fast approaching. Arlene plans to take this opportunity to drive her business toward more profitability.

Arlene's life is never without challenges, both in her business and in her personal life. Nonetheless, she stays focused on the opportunities that lie ahead, and not on the failures of yesterday or the worries of today.


*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: additional stock to replenish current inventory

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma A., 31, is from Capucao Ozamiz City. She is married and has one infant child. To make a living, Vilma owns and operates a motor transport services business. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Vilma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vilma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP to repair an existing vehicle in order to provide better services. This will be her second loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair an existing vehicle in order to provide better services.

loans.name: Pidson

texts.en:
Pidson is a thirty-year-old married man with four children renting a house in Fort Portal, Uganda with a family dream of building a house for his family to reside in. He is into welding and has been in metal fabrication for eleven years; the business is still in its boom stage and his mission is to own a popular workshop servicing the whole region.

Pidson intends to use the loan to buy raw materials such as metals.

loans.use: purchasing metals to use as raw materials

loans.name: Karen

texts.en: Karen P. is from the village of Malibangcao, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 32 years old. Karen is married and has an infant. To make a living, Karen owns and operates a motorcycle-transport service. Karen has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 10,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Karen joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Karen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from GDMPC. Karen is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to repair an existing vehicle for better service. This will be the second loan taken out by Karen from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair an existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Martin

texts.en:
Martin, age 34, is married to Mary Nyarua. Together, they have three children aged 8, 10 and 13 years. He has a retail shop where he sells, detergents, tea leaves, sugar, salt, flour, and cooking oil, among other items. 

Martin was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend who had benefited from KADET.

He has been running this business for 12 years and this is the fourth loan he is getting from KADET. He intends to use it to add more stock to the shop, so that he can get better returns, especially in the festive season. 

Besides the retail shop, Martin is doing both crop and animal farming. With the anticipated profits, he will improve his farming activities so that he can diversify his trade.

He desires to give his family a better life, including a good education for his children.

loans.use: to buy more stock for his shop

loans.name: Benson Mutua

texts.en: Benson K. is 56 years old and married to Alice who contributes to the family income. They have two children. Benson has been running his retail shop for five years with an income of Kshs. 20,000 per month. This is his second loan from  KADET LTD after successfully repaying the previous one. He hopes to be a leading retailer and start a wholesale store and give his children a quality education and improve their living standards

loans.use: To buy flour, sugar and tea.

loans.name: Anastacio

texts.en:
Anastacio P. is from the village of San Andres. He is 50 years old. Anastacio is married and has 5 children. To make a living, Anastacio owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Anastacio has been engaged in his business for over 30 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Anastacio joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anastacio has successfully repaid a previous loan of 26,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Anastacio is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Anastacio from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en: Nicholas is a twenty-eight-year-old married man with a child living in his house in Fort Portal, Uganda with a desire to own a car for the family. For twenty years he has been a driver for a tea estate and has also been planting tea. His business dream is to own an estate in the next five years as the venture is very feasible. Nicholas needs the loan to buy seedlings to plant.

loans.use: Buying seedlings to plant

loans.name: Lucia Nyokabi

texts.en: Lucia K. is 42 years old and married to john Kungu who contributes to the family income. She has been making porridge and selling it from one place to another where her clients are.  She has been in the business for a period of two years with a profit of Kshs. 39,700 per month. This is her second loan from KADET LTD and she plans to use it to buy a dairy cow to increase her profit. She hopes to start a restaurant in the future and improve the living standard of her family.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Enhtaivan

texts.en:
Enhtaivan B. is 57 years old and lives with his wife and son in Hovd province, Mongolia. He and his family all live together in a house with a fence. His wife is retired and collects a pension. 

Enhtaivan operates a taxi service in the local community. He began his business in 2006 and has gained a lot of business experience over this short period. His son is a driver, too. The son  works alternatively with his father. Also, during the summertime, Enhtaivan operates a deep water well. For the future he wants to buy a "Bongo" car for his son's taxi business. 

Enhtaivan is a simple and kind-hearted man. He is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan in order to make necessary repairs for his car and to buy new car for his son.

loans.use: To buy new car and to make necessary repairs on the old one

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
As the saying goes, opportunity knocks only once. Edna E. knows this truth and grabs every opportunity that comes her way. Edna, 43, reached high school and is married to Emelito, a driver. Together they are raising three children, of whom one is in high school, one in elementary, and the other one already working. Together, they live in Pasay City, Philippines.

Edna presently runs a sari-sari (variety) store, in which she sells items that are needed daily by neighbors in her community. Products on her shelves range from soap bars to candies and energy drinks to rice. Having been at least 15 years in business, she knows to pay her dues on time. She also has an excellent reputation with her fellow community partners in CCT* and, most importantly, her customers. Monthly she is able to earn an average of Php 8,800.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a Php 20,000 loan. She intends to use this money to purchase more products for her store, all the more now that the Christmas season is fast approaching. Edna plans to take this opportunity to drive her businesses toward more profitability.

Edna's life is never without challenges, both in her business and personal life. Nonetheless, she stays focused on the opportunities that lie ahead, and not on the failures of yesterday or the worries of today.


*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: additional stock to replenish current inventory

loans.name: Minerva

texts.en:
With working capital, Minerva’s sewing business will keep on growing and she will be able to offer good service and meet the increasing demand of her regular customer. Through the support of KIVA lenders, Minerva hopes soon to see changes in her family's quality of living and to see them moving forward out from poverty.
 
She is now requesting another ASHI loan through Kiva amounting of 10,000 PHP to purchase fabrics and to support her sewing business.  The capital will fund further expansion of the family venture to support Minerva’s dreams for her children of completing college degrees and having a decent way of life. 

Her long-term goal is to have a tailoring shop a year from now so that she can give opportunity of employment to others. Minerva aims to maintain a sustainable business over the long term.

loans.use: To purchase cotton fabric to maintain her sewing business

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is a twenty-two-year-old ambitious young man living in his own house in Fort Portal, Uganda and his family desire is to buy a good deal of land before he marries. He is a motorcycle rider and has been in this business for three years. His business dream is to own a motorcycle as he is just an employee.

Peter intends to use the credit to buy a motorcycle.

loans.use: Buying a motorcycle for transport business

loans.name: Alex

texts.en:
Alex S. is from the village of San Andres. He is 33 years old. Alex is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Alex owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Alex has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Alex joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alex has successfully repaid a previous loan of 18,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Alex is requesting a new loan of 24,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Alex from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Margret

texts.en: Margret is forty-eight years old, a single mother of four children, living in a rented house in Fort Portal, Uganda. She has a retail shop and a bar with an experience of five years in such business, Margret needs the loan to purchase beers and sodas for sale.

loans.use: Purchasing sodas and beers for sale

loans.name: Esnarda

texts.en:
As the saying goes, opportunity knocks only once. Esnarda M. knows this truth and grabs every opportunity that comes her way. Esnarda, 63, reached elementary school. She is a widow who raised her three working children. Together, they live in Pasay City, Philippines.

Esnarda presently runs a sari-sari (variety) store, in which she sells items that are needed daily by neighbors in her community. Products on her shelves range from soap bars to candies and energy drinks to rice. Also, she has an alkaline water-making machine with which she adds to the income of the family. Having been at least five years in business, she knows how to pay her dues on time. She also has an excellent reputation with her fellow community partners in CCT* and, most important, her customers. Monthly, she is able to earn an average of 10,000 Philippines pesos (Php).

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a Php 44,000 loan. She intends to use this money to purchase more products for her store, all the more now that the Christmas season is fast approaching. She also plans to charge up her alkaline water business so that it will also become profitable. Esnarda plans to take this opportunity to drive her businesses toward more profitability.

Esnarda's life is never without challenges, both in her business and personal life. Nonetheless, she stays focused on the opportunities that lie ahead, and not on the failures of yesterday or the worries of today.


*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: Additional stock to replenish current store inventory

loans.name: Benson Nzuma

texts.en:
Benson Nzuma, aged 33, operates a motorcycle transport business in Tala town. He transports customers along Kikomba, Kivaani, and Kagundo routes. He is married to Mary Muthio, a teacher by profession, and together they have three children — one in class four, and 6-month-old twins. Benson was introduced to KADET by the credit officer in charge of the Tala office.

Benson has been running this business for a period of two years and his monthly profit is Kshs 8,000. This loan of Kshs 74,871 is his first loan from KADET and he intends to use the money to buy another motorbike. If the loan boosts business, he will buy more motorcycles and take on other routes. He dreams of having many motorbikes running in many routes. He describes himself as honest, helpful, kind and hardworking.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe M. is from the village of Kinagay Norte Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 45 and widowed with three school-aged children. To make a living, Fe owns a general store. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month. 

In 2010, Fe joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan  from GDMPC and is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Fe from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units office covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.
